reviewText:
Let me start off by saying, don't expect much from this game. I feel like it is a game that could be victim to overhype.
I went in merely with the intention of clearing some dreaded Steam backlog and hadn't seen anything about the game in over a year, forgetting how nice the screenshots looked.
Therefore, going in with no expectations whatsoever, I came away having played one of, if not my favourite, game of all time.

This game gets better and better as it goes on, so don't expect to be blown away from the start. It is the grand sense that I really had been on an adventure that was left with me at the end, and being 3-4 hours long it feels like I had taken part in an interactive movie (having played it in one sitting).

But it is definitely a game, and the gameplay was just the right amount of fun. A lot of clever design choices means the game continually flows, adding to that sense of adventure. The puzzles aren't particularly difficult, but never did I feel like I was having my intelligence insulted either.  There were times when I anticpated having to do something again, or something similar to what I had just done and had a feeling of tedium, only to be pleasantly surprised that the developers recognised that, and changed it up completely.  I wish more developers would recognise that a game doesn't have to be long and filled with fluff to make it good. Three hours of quality is plenty for someone with limited time to play games.

The story isn't complex but it will leave an impression on most people. And how they go about conveying that story was also a clever touch. The game has no understandable dialogue, using only an invented language with no subtitles to get it's message across and I'm surprised at how well it does this when, in my opinion, the character models are the worst part of the game. They look out of place against the fantastic backdrops that make you stop and sit on a bench to look at the vistas, even when you were planning on rushing through a game to get it off your checklist. So at first, I wasn't struck. However, despite this, the sense of emotion you get from the characters is really rather deep and by the end you're completely invested. Most of the game is spent in third person and you won't be up close enough to see the poor character details anyway.

The other thing most people will comment on are the controls. You control both brothers, from different sides of the keyboard and I can see why a lot of people will mark them down negatively. It is often difficult to get them both running in merely a straight line. I argue though that the controls are perfect for the type of game it is and add a layer of complexity to it that stops the game feeling too easy. Like I said, the puzzles aren't difficult at all, but the controls make you have to think about what you're doing, and I have to say, the times when you simultaneously have both brothers doing something complex, or even just running down a path and crossing over each other and turning at slightly different times, but doing so accurately, feels really good.

There are a few negative points to the game, a couple of which rear their head almost straight away. As mentioned, the character details aren't great. Then, you come to the first puzzle.  You have to raise a platform, and it's immensely tedious, especially if you let go, and you have to start again. This platform raising happens once more in the game, and if  anything is even more tedious. Maybe I did it wrong. But it's over in a couple of minutes and overall doesn't affect the game. Lastly, texture glitches. In two cutscenes, some textures didn't load. It was only a rug and a chest of drawers, so not game breaking, but noticable. Also in one part, a shadow didn't load that was part of the mechanics of the situation, and I died. I didn't realise why until I started again and saw the shadow now loaded.

Overall, I can't believe I had this game sitting in my library for so long being unappreciated. I also feel bad for spending so little on it. I can't quite remember what I paid, but it probably wasn't enough.

Play this game, don't expect much and you're sure to have a good time.

reviewText:
This game features a beautiful fairy tale, which tells a story about two Brothers trying to find a cure for their dying father. Swedish film director J. Fares and Starbreeze studio really managed to make this fantasy world alive, set in varied and beautiful locations. Story is simple, but emotionally strong and creates a bond between two brothers similar to ICO. Gameplay is kind of original and lets you control both brothers at the same time. It works rather well except some awkward controls in a few levels. Sound simply can not be missed. You won't understand what characters say, but animations, gestures tell that with no words. Music is very well done and is a huge part of the atmosphere.
And don't forget to collect all achievements, they add even more to the story.

At the end, Brothers is truly a work of art and despite a short length it is a journey you will be immersed and won't forget. Yeah, it`s one of the best games in this year.

reviewText:
A couple of times you get to play a game that can make you feel completely worn down, emotionally speaking. This game did that for me. It doesn't happen that often, although there are some great titles out there that are as worth it as this one.

Let me start by saying that the puzzles are not that difficult, which could be a turn-off for the hardcore gamers, but the game-play (controlling both brothers at the same time), narritive, surroundings and the story itself make up for it and then some.

The way the characters just speak in what seems a 'made-up' or 'children's language', which you can understand instantly, is one of those points I really liked. I think it made the story stronger then with actual words in a spoken language.

The story is about two brothers (surprise!) that have to work together to get a potion for their father who is sick and on the brink of death. To get this potion they have to travel through forests, mountains and ice-covered seas to get to the 'Tree of life'. On this journey they get help from surprising figures and have to help each other across rivers, canyons and other obstacles.

And if any of the players say they did not tear up or even cried big tears at the end... well, they might have lied. I know I cried. Big time. Not with actual sobbing and runny nose, but still... A story about sacrifice, perseverence, hardship and an ending like that... Yeah, that just hit me hard.

reviewText:
tl;dr version - Go get it! And if you can, play with a controller over a keyboard. (CAN be played with a keyboard despite the way it's been advertised)

A beautiful game that's focused mostly on the story and creative ways to play rather than a challenging gameplay.
This game can be emotional, funny, mysterious and epic. The whole game can be completed in a single sitting, yes it's short. But that doesn't make the game any less impressive. The story itself revolves around 2 brothers and the way they've implemented the controller to interact with them is simply brilliant. Hence it's highly recommended to be played with a controller over a keyboard. The game has a deep message behind it, about life, morality and overcoming struggles. And the music, I fell in love with it instantly as soon as I heard it. It's absolutely perfect. It knows when it needs to be serious, epic and just downright silly. The art style the devs went for is great as well. Some scenes are completely breathtaking, combined with the beautiful music scores.

Not a lot of games could pull off what this game manages to do. Needless to say, this game has become one of my favourite games of all time.

When it comes to cons, I don't really have any with this game other than a couple of bug encounters that didn't really pull me out of the game.

reviewText:
I had been meaning to play this game for a while but never got around to it. It wasn't until a friend of mine posted on my Steam profile telling me to give it a go did I seriously download it on my laptop and made a genuine effort to put some time into it.
The first thing that you'll notice about this game is that there's no real spoken dialogue. I mean the characters do make sounds and seem to have some verbal exchanges but it's more like Simlish. If The Sims has taught us anything in the last 20ish years though is that you don't need to understand the language to understand a story. This is actually the biggest lesson I'm reminded of as I live somewhere where I don't understand what 90% of the people around me are saying on a daily basis, but I digress.

Brothers features a beautiful rustic fantasy atmospheric adventure almost as if it was straight out of a fairy tale. You and your brother go on a journey across the land to find a tree that could save your dying father's life. Despite it being primarily about our two main characters and their journey you get to meet a lot of different inhabitants that help you along the way. Also you see the relationship and personalities between the younger and older brother in how they interact with each other and those they meet.

You'll find both have skills that move the game along. As we all know the older brother excels in strength you find out early on that the little brother also has some advantages due to his size and pulls just as much as weight as his counterpart.

Somewhere along the way though you'll find out that despite the cheery magical surroundings that the fairy tale aspect might be more ancient fairy tales where things don't always work out the way you expect it would and not the Disney type where people live happily ever after. That however, makes this game all the more compelling as at some point I was playing through tears. This isn't too much a spoiler but I think when a game can elicit emotional responses without saying a word that speaks volumes of the story and characters.

I was sad when my adventure finally came to an end but I felt satisfied and a real sense of growth in the characters without any leveling up system or super powers. Overall you have great graphics, a touching story with endearing characters. It was a pleasure to play, even with the sometimes unfamiliar controller mechanics where you're using each side to move both brothers simultaneously. I wholeheartedly recommend this game as one everyone should experience.

reviewText:
Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a third-person linear co-op game and inspired by games such as Ico and Shadow of the Colossus due to their similarities in gameplay and aesthetics.

The premise of the game is following two brothers, Naie (eldest) and Naiee (youngest), through their journey across different lands searching for a magical tree which has the cure that can save their dying father. Being a very narratively driven game, revealing any details about the story would ruin much of the gameâ€™s charm since that is its main driving force.

The game plays exactly like a co-op puzzle-platformer where you control the two brothers through their journey. Throughout the game, using a controller is strongly recommended as playing it on keyboard, whilst still doable, can result in some awkward coordination between the two controllable protagonists when they start bumping into each other or objects like two drunks. The actual gameplay itself is satisfying due to the nice blend of â€œpuzzlesâ€ requiring both brothersâ€™ participation throughout most of the game. The difficulty of these â€œpuzzlesâ€ may eventually feel disappointing after a while as they do not provide any concrete challenge to the player(s) (hence the inverted commas), although that might have been deliberate for the integrity of the gameâ€™s pace. Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is, indeed, one of those games where the difficulty requires being at a minimum for the narrative to be at full throttle. Remember, no one wants to get constantly stuck solving complex puzzles in a narratively-driven game as it subsequently ruins the gameâ€™s pace.

However, where it lacks in challenging puzzles or even perhaps rewarding gameplay, it compensates for its narrative which in actual fact is the heart of this game. The journey, albeit disappointedly short, transports you in a world where you believe you are in a place like Middle-Earth; travelling through various mesmerising landscapes on your quest for the cure while the suiting soundtrack plays in the background. All of its narrative is achieved rather through visuals and gestures as there is not any comprehendible dialogue in the entire game. That in itself is commendable as not many games can pull it off as successfully as Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons does. Frankly, each gesture or visual representation is easily and surprisingly understandable. Besides all that, the game also offers in its storytelling a handful of moments of happiness, laughter, seriousness and sadness without feeling schizophrenic with its mood shifts. The gameâ€˜s narrative can have some amazing set-pieces, but also a couple of clumsy ones.

And that is as much as Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons can offer to players. On top of its colourful charm, or even some of its darker undertones, there are two main complains I personally had with this game in my first playthrough which ultimately felt detrimental to an extent towards my overall enjoyment. On a technical level, I encountered three game-breaking bugs which would not allow me to continue to the next area. Whilst two of them were solved by looking up online forums, the latter required restarting two prior chapters since simply restarting the current one was not sufficient to solve the problem. As of now, I still have no idea how those bugs triggered when it seems that the majority of people never even encountered them in the first place. Still, having to restart two complete chapters is bothersome. Then lastly, the ending. I will honestly be one of those in the minority who was not totally satisfied with the storyâ€™s conclusion nor did it have an impact on me. Even as I wish to critically evaluate it in this review, I cannot do that without simply spoiling it. But I will say this: I understood what they tried to achieve with the coming of age approach, but reflecting back through the entire journey, the writing at this point was sloppy and felt more of a cop out in the end to me. It also made me realise how Naie was not fleshed out as a character as much as his younger brother, Naiee, making a certain event not as effective as the developers would have hoped for, to me at least. Perhaps that is because the story might have been moving a bit too fast for things to fully develop.

Conclusively, Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is one those video games where you delve in exclusively for the storytelling experience. Nothing more, nothing less.  Without even sounding remotely pretentious, It is hardly the â€œmasterpieceâ€ everyone clams it to be, although it will definitely, and respectfully, leave a lasting impression for many people regardless, especially for youngsters. But not for everyone. Mechanically, it has a solid co-op experience with extremely easy puzzles to solve and backed up by artistically appealing sceneries, a fitting soundtrack and a simple, yet immersive, narrative despite a few clumsy set-pieces and a somewhat unsatisfying ending. At full price, however, I would definitely not recommend this due to its short length (2-3 hours at most) and limited replayability as there is not much reason to revisit it anytime soon now that you know how the story wraps up. Conversely, considering it always goes as low as Â£1 during virtually any Steam sales, there is absolutely no excuse not to try this, and that is why I am recommending it in the end. Despite some of its flaws, I truly had fun playing it and thought it managed to do what it was aiming for mostly pretty well, even if I will probably not reflect too much upon it in the near future.

reviewText:
Rating: 10/10 must buy - worth full price and then some ( WORK OF ART status)

Summary: Emotionally charged and beautifully designed adventure puzzle game. Can be played without controller but dont do it, use a 2 stick controller. Hits right in the feelings in the best possible way. No one will be left unmoved by the game.

Long review (SPOILER FREE):
Game is set in a fantasy world in which you play as two brothers on a epic quest to acquire a certain item. It is a very mature tale about growing up, brotherly bonds, effects of  trauma on a young person, overcoming those traumas and acceptance of death as part of life.

Art direction is really good and make the world seem very alive which in turn makes you get really immersed in the game. Game is not long around 2,5h (4h if you stop to take in scenery) but in that short time it will take you on a emotional roller coaster ranging from heartwarming to heartbreaking. You will not feel like you were cheated by how short it is in the end, it will feel perfectly timed.

I can honestly say this is one of the few games that ever induced such deep emotions and cathartic feeling at the end. I am talking about The Walking Dead Clementine affection or MGS Sniper Wolf death scene level of emotions. This game will stick with me for the rest of my life. Please play this game in ONE sitting.

Characters in this game speak in a made up language and there are no subtitles yet design is so masterful you will never not understand what is happening or get lost or not understand a puzzle. In fact i was impressed that i developed such strong feelings for the brothers despite it. Puzzles range from easy to medium. Sometimes they are a bit hard" just because you are most likely not used to controlling 2 characters at once using both analog sticks and R2 L2 triggers. Personally i did not find them clunky it worked really well for such a design.

This game was simply amazing! Although there are still some things that could be better and need work, the things they did right really stand out and exemplify the game in a great way. First lets talk about the bad things.

One thing I truly enjoyed about his game is that it does not hold your hand. New little mechanics are added into the puzzles and will require you to think a little which is refreshing from 99% of games where everything is handed to you instantly. Another they did correctly was the controls. They were extremely innovative and well made, easy to use and although i would get my thumbs tangled, it felt smooth and overall nice. The story is a cliche, but thru the gameplay and interactions, it really was quite good. The game never truly dragged out when compared to most games and the visuals were nice. Overall, this is a solid game with great controls, a moving story, fun puzzles and nice visuals. It does have its bugs and glitches but with some research you should be able to find a fix and continue on your journey. Highly recommend to everyone.

reviewText:
I can see why this has been on so many GOTY lists. The journey you take with the brothers is extraordinary. Closest thing I can liken it to is Ico, Shadow of the Colossus and Dark Souls, except if those had been made by Astrid Lindgren.

A couple scenes had janky animation, and at one time I felt frustration at not knowing what to do, but those issues don't matter on the whole. The world design and story more than make up for it. Critics like Adam Sessler & TotalBiscuit had hyped up the ending quite a bit, and probably as a result I didn't find it outstanding in any way. It ended like it should, but it wasn't the high point for me. The best scenes in the game were the ones which were completely optional. For example at one point you meet a man who has lost his family in a fire and is about to kill himself. I'm glad I played it. I had seen clips from it and heard the hype from those who played it, but it didn't really prepare me from what the game is like. Don't miss it.

reviewText:
A charming tale which is told by sight and sound rather than traditional scripting.
The two titular sons are brothers who must journey to assist their sick father. A journey that will call upon both of them to work together to overcome the sometimes hostile environment to reach their goal.

The mechanics and premise of the game are beautifully simple and excellently excecuted.
The left thumbstick of your gamepad controls the movement of the older brother with the left trigger handling any of many interactions with the environment and/or the younger brother. The younger of the two is likewise controlled (you guessed it) by the right thumbstick and trigger.

It takes a little bit of getting used to but clicks into place quickly enough and feels really rewarding once you get to grips with it.

The puzzles never seem to get too difficult but require enough thought to not seem contrived and they never infuriate.

Anyone who has ever played Kuri Kuri mix on the PS2 will enjoy this immediately, as well as feeling right at home. The main difference here being the excellent way the developers have made two main characters that you can instantly empathise with.

Ultimately I would recommend this at full price. At the holiday price it is quite simply a steal. Don't miss this one.

Additionally I would like to add that I am playing this game using my motherboards onboard graphics. And it runs fine. It should run really well on older systems.

reviewText:
Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons was developed by the company Starbreeze Studios, who were responsible for games like The Chronicles of Riddick games, The Darkness and Payday 2 and directed by famous Swedish film director Josef Fares.

The two Brothers, Naiee (the younger brother) and Naia (the older brother) become united as one not only by the plot but with the help of the gameâ€™s mechanics and narration. Thrust out their village and into a gorgeous and almost realistic storybook, the Brotherâ€™s only weapons are their minds and their only resource is each other.

The brothers then embark on their epic journey through the beautiful landscape of villages, hills, mountains, caves and even the valley of dead giants and trolls that went to war with each other on a very bloody battlefield. At the same time the Brothers also faced challenges like the local bully, a farmer's aggressive dog, and deadly wolves.  Along with these challenges the Brothers also undertake a journey of self-discovery as they learn to work together to overcome each challenge. They even learn and work out how to help out the various characters they meet during their adventure - like reuniting a friendly pair of trolls, saving a man attempting suicide, aiding an inventor, freeing a badly injured griffin that help them before succumbing to its injures and even a girl from being scarified by a blood cult.

The dialogue throughout the game is in an artificial language and there are no signs to really provide any type of information to the player in regards to where you must go. You just follow the path, trusting that the brothers are heading the right way. And this parallels the relationship between the brothers: although you canâ€™t understand what they say to one another, you know they love and look out for one another.

The gameâ€™s visuals are gorgeous to look at and the game rarely lets a few minutes pass without offering some sort of staggeringly gorgeous landscape to ogle. There are even benches scattered throughout the game for the Brothers to sit on. The player is given permission to stop and enjoy the vistas; which are not only beautiful but ram home how vast a world Naia and Naiee have to traverse and, by extension, how vital their relationship is to their own survival. The game makes it so clear that the characters themselves are impressed by what they see. The soundtrack was equally as gorgeous. The Swedish vocals added that extra charm when it came to cut scenes and often provided the atmosphere and told the player what they should feel at that precise moment.

The player controls both brothers simultaneously, each mapped to an analogue stick, as that makes button mashing impossible when it comes to puzzle solving. Every action from grab the ledge above" to "play the harp" is performed with the triggers. When I first played this game I did find it quite hard to control both the brothers the same time. Usually one would end up running into a wall. Ultimately the control scheme acts as a defining piece of storytelling. The control scheme is actually very simple

reviewText: While from the perspective of level design and gameplay mechanics this title leaves a bit to be desired (indeed, many of the obstacles are overcome with much the same solution), the stunning beauty and artistry presented more than compensate, rendering this more an interactive story than a game in the normal sense.  There are no side-quests, nor is there any real purpose in honing one's skills, at least not beyond learning how to control the two characters simultaneously.  However, if you enjoy contemplative nature hikes, appreciate minutiae, and are even remotely of an empathic disposition, this one is definitely worth your time.  There are moments that will stay with you well past the meager 3-hour duration.\n\nFrom a technical standpoint, the game ran with barely a hiccup on my 8-year-old laptop, so just about anything with at least an integrated graphics chipset should have no trouble.  While a controller is not strictly necessary, it is important to note that the keyboard configuration cannot be changed (wasd+space and arrow keys+right control); since you will be controlling both characters at once, this requires a keyboard that supports many concurrent key presses.  Though it is playable, the recommendation of having a controller is a good one.

reviewText:
9/10 - This is one of the greatest games with genius story telling.

It has beautiful design and unique gameplay mechanics - controlling two characters at the same time in order to solve puzzles and progress further. Storyline is just brilliant. Even the game is short, you get to experience so much in this adventure on every step, and it gets more and more emotional toward the end. Not many games in history achieved such level of involvement.

The only bad thing is that its gameplay extremely easy to the degree it is often boring or just inexistent. It is ridiculously linear, you have just one narrow route (or a couple parallel ones) and you can't leave it or fall of a cliff, even characters jump over a pit on your way automatically when you approach it. Despite quite innovative control mechanics and occasional interesting puzzles, you still don't get anything challenging to solve with reasonable amount of effort, everything is pretty much obvious right away. All that almost excludes failure state of the game in practice, even my first death was way past the middle of playthrough.

To sum it up - it is a great experience you should not miss if you like games like that, or just want to experience what the game offers. Just don't expect much out of an actual gameplay and ignore linearity - you will be able to appreciate the game to the fullest.

reviewText:
Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a very powerful and emotional game, which manages to deliver a beautiful and captivating story without any dialogue or written story-telling. All the story-telling is done by the character's body languages or the game simply showing that something is happening in the area. It has a gorgeous art style and some beautifully designed levels, both visually and how you progress through them. They're very linear though, with only some minor exploration leading to a nice view or something to do for an achievement. Your goal in this game is to find some magical tree and bring back some water of the healing well inside of it, in order to cure your ill father.

The gameplay is quite innovative, putting the player in control of both characters at once, using only one controller. The left thumb stick and trigger control one character's movement and actions, and the right stick and trigger are used for the other character. Keyboard support has been added some time ago as well, but I can't vouch for how well that works as I only played it with a controller. It's pretty tricky to get used to at first, and I often had to move one character at a time or pause shortly before releasing a character's action button to make sure I wouldn't accidentally let the other character fall to his death.

Most puzzles and obstacles require the brothers to work together and make up for each other's weaknesses. The big brother is the strongest one so he will be pulling heavy switches and carrying things, as well as boosting his little brother to higher platforms. The little brother never learned to swim due to being traumatized by seeing his mother drown in front of his eyes, so he clings onto his bigger brother when they need to swim through a river or pond. But because he is more nimble he manages to get to some places where the big brother can't get to and then helps him get past. A lot of the time you will also need to use both brothers at once to move something heavy or interact with two things that are spread apart at once.

The ending is very emotional, but obviously I can't talk about that because it would spoil the entire experience for anyone who hasn't played this yet. And if you haven't, I really recommend you do. It goes really cheap during sales, and it only takes about three hours to complete. Despite being so very short, it still delivers a great experience that's really worth your time, especially if you're open to the more artsy and touching games out there. It would be cool to play this game with someone else online, but then that would also take away the innovative controls which are part of what makes this game such a great experience.

reviewText:
This game made me cry. Twice.

Which is a good thing - I like it when fictional stuff elicits tears from my eyes; I call it â€˜resonating with artâ€™. (What? Itâ€™s better than that â€˜ninjas cutting onionsâ€™ cliche people always use... right?)

On the subject of cliches, this game has many: a convenient sunset, a generic premise to set up a generic conflict, a flashback recalling happier times, and at some point a backstabber.

The game is also linear, and short (3 hours). But hey, sometimes itâ€™s fun to play a linear and short game. (People complain about linearity, but if every game had an open world, well, weâ€™d have a dump truck-full of terrible open-world games.)

The difference with this game is that its linearity serves a purpose: thereâ€™s a constant build-up, and just the faintest sense of a ticking clock, of inevitability.

Even the cliches add rather than detract; they make the story seem innocent, the adventure seem mild, the characters seem... invincible. They keep things straight-forward, because straight and forward is precisely where the game wants you to go. Even the controls, which will take time to adjust to, are as basic as they get.

But for all its simplicity, Brothers doesnâ€™t let you grow bored. Thereâ€™s never two of the same puzzle, and the settings change regularly. (I have a short attention span, but this game never once lost its magic.) You might â€˜dieâ€™ a few times, but youâ€™re never really stuck, and even in the few places where a sense of urgency might be felt, thereâ€™s never much tension. Itâ€™s the kind of game that you can play at leisure, while also being very fun.

The setting, mind you, will at some point take an abrupt turn - in literal terms, youâ€™ll start to go downhill instead of up - and from there the mood will start to shift. Just wait.

Everything, from the settings to the cliches, will there reveal itself as a tool, a gameplay feature employed by the developer to serve a purpose - but itâ€™s a purpose I shanâ€™t spoil. Even the controller, which youâ€™d spent a decent time mastering, will turn out to have, all along, been a pawn expertly positioned in storytelling.

Towards the end every piece will culminate like a well-choreographed dance, a superbly-structured film. And in many ways this game is a film, but itâ€™s the kind of film that the developer goes to lengths to make sure youâ€™re a part of. Enjoy it.

Because you may not want to play this game twice. Youâ€™ll certainly want others to play it, to experience it with child-like eyes; but youâ€™ll also wish that you could return to when your own eyes were child-like - when, you might say, times were happier. Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is just one of those games that you can never un-play.

10/10

P.S. I purchased this game on sale (80% off, I think). Whether you think it's worth the full price will depend on if, for the same price, you'd purchase a 3-hour film that you knew would be great to watch.

reviewText:
Summary: Brothers is an engaging, fun, frustrating and immersive afternoon's fun - requiring a pad.

It's a tough thing to talk much about Brothers - A Tale Of Two Sons. The game is compact; so there's little you can draw reference to without spoiling anything, and to ruin this beautiful little tale would do the reader a great disservice. That in itself should serve as a recommendation, though it comes with several caveats.

Firstly, there is only one reason why you would logically ever play Brothers twice, and that's to get achievements. As sad a statement as that is in many games, here it's in the games' favour, as the achievements here take the form of vignettes which occur off Brother's beaten (and entirely linear) path. These brief scenes take a variety of tones and forms, and some are more enjoyable than others (of course). The merit of this approach is that the achievements enhance the game rather than detract from it, and for this Brothers should be applauded. Find all of these asides from the main tale though, and that's it - nothing more to see here.

So, the game itself. Brothers is an isometric overhead adventure, in which you guide the titular big and little brothers (who call one another Naia and Naiee in the game world's language, whatever those words may mean) around various obstacles on their journey to find a cure for their ailing father. As we have come to expect, the game and soundtrack are both beautiful, with a visually realised and aurally rounded world waiting to be explored. The manner of exploration is probably the most talked about and easily discussed mechanic of the game, which to summarily recap, involves simultaneous control of both brothers. On a standard gamepad set-up, the left stick controls the big brother, right stick the little brother, with left and right triggers serving as each character's action/interaction button, and left/right bumper rotating the camera. This control scheme may be both the game's key draw and most off-putting mechanic depend on how you personally handle the remapping of ingrained controller use - the operation is fairly fluid and has a gentle enough curve to allow you to get used to it, and I personally found the system engaging and enjoyable, but I can see the same aspects frustrating and annoying many gamers.

Nonetheless, overcome the fact that you WILL at times be constantly running one brother into a wall while the other calls out to his counterpart for no reason, simply because the little brother is positioned to the left of the big brother and your mind has once again mapped the left stick to the left character and vice-versa, and you have a wonderful ride ahead of you.

And you will need a controller. Yes, the game has keyboard controls. Be aware however that the game itself will warn you that it is designed, specifically, to be controlled with a pad. On a keyboard certain tasks requiring rotation of both thumbsticks simultaneously... do not map well. I can't honestly recommend the game to anyone without a controller.

As to the story, events and specifics of the world - they should all be experienced for oneself. So long as you have some sort of empathy within you, this is a great little journey which will draw you in fully for three to four hours. The puzzles aren't particularly challenging at any part, there's no choices or branching story lines - and you won't mind. It's refreshing how streamlined and conservative Brothers is with it's mechanics, puzzles and set-pieces, and it deserves to be played both for and because of these aspects. The tone, whist initially whimsical, darkens considerably, to the point where I'd advise against playing the game with younger children. To give it a cinematic comparison, it starts off in Jim Henson's Labyrinth, moves into The Never-Ending Story, and ends... not joyfully. However; I wouldn't change a thing about it.

It is also very worth saying that just because you'll see the entire game in one or two play-throughs, it is still extremely re-playable and enjoyable each time. I fired up the game to check out the keyboard controls while writing this review and I felt an urge to play again immediately, which would make a fourth run at the game.

This really is a beautiful, innovative and rollicking yarn which asks for very little from the player and gives a ton back. The only hold-ups are the aforementioned potential control frustrations, and for those to whom it's a factor, the price. Not wishing to seem â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥rdly, for your average player, Â£12 for a three-hour game isn't great. When you take into account what you get for that price of entry, I'd have to say that yes, it is worth it, but I can't say I paid that for it as I picked up a cheap key. At half price this game is an absolute steal and should be purchased without reservation, at full price, give the points raised here a little thought before committing.

8.5/10

reviewText:
This is the game that delivers on the promise of narrative-entwined gameplay that we glimpsed a year ago in Journey. It'll be remembered (and dissected, and copied) for one specific, powerful moment, but the game's true success is the way it uses its 'single-player co-op' gameplay to define the brothers as individuals and a team in the hours leading up to its climax. Even better, the whimsical, often brutal fairy tale design of its Scandinavian-themed world makes it easily one of the year's best-looking games.

In terms of tone, the game is equal parts Ico, Journey and Limbo. There's an innocence and beauty to the world, but an undercurrent of melancholy and danger. It gets dark. The game uses a fictional language and, aside from its very first minutes, features no text or prompts. But you'll never have a problem understanding what's being said, thanks to the expressiveness of the models and voice work. The controls are as minimal as the UI: each brother is tied to one analog stick and one trigger for movement and context-sensitive actions.

The gameplay revolves around solid, but light, platforming and puzzle-solving. The real draw is how well the gameplay serves the story and atmosphere. The role the brothers play in solving physical puzzles or traversing the environment is defined not only by their sizes, but by their personalities. I'd like to give a few examples, but I don't want to spoil much for you. Suffice to say, their interactions with each other, and with the other characters in the world, feel natural.

There's real wonder and fun in this title. Enjoy.

reviewText:
Spellbinding.
That is the only way I can describe this game.
Having finished it mere minutes ago, the effects left by it still linger in my memory.

As with every game, it has Pro's and Cons, but the Pro's faar outweigh the cons.

Pros:
-A journey you will not forget
-Landscapes that are Wallpaper Worthy. Beautifull.
-Really inventive control of the charactors. Control BOTH of the brothers on your gamepad.
Big Brother on Left Stick & Left Trigger and Little Brother on Right Stick & Trigger.
-The Story will grab you and refuse to let you go until the credits roll.
-The first ever good game that is directed and written by a Film Director.
-Solid Puzzle Solving Gameplay. Had alot of fun.
-Enchanting Music. Hope you have a good sound system to appreciate it!

Cons:
-TOO SHORT! Finished it in about 6 hours :/ Even while failing in a few sections.
For the cover charge of $15, this is a tough pill to swallow. Thankfully, I bought this during the Steam Winter Sales 2014 for $7.49, which is alot more reasonable in my opinion.
-BUGGY! It has happened to me only once, but the only way to resolve it was to restart the entire chapter :/
-The control scheme may be abit more than some people can handle, even for me it took awhile to get used to it.
-When the game is over, its really over. No Replayability what-so-ever. No New Game + mode, no extra features like directors cut, nothing.

TL;DR Buy this game ASAP, but at a discounted price. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Rating: 9/10

What is it?
Action/Adventure game where you control two brothers with each joystick on the controller solving puzzles as you progress through the story/enivroments.

The Good:

+What really stands out for me is the gorgeous graphics,atmoshpere, and beautiful vistas. Its a game where you just want to stop and look at everything.

+Varied environments throughout the game make the world feel more real and alive and provide a nice change of scenery

+The game feels like a grand adventure in the span of only 3 hours. It does such a good job of the pacing and the puzzles that it feels like you just completed an epic quest.

+Controller both brothers at the same time can be frustrating however it adds an extra element to the gameplay, and provides some interesting scenarios and puzzles.

+Simple and yet effective story conveyed with no dialogue

The Bad

-The game is very easy, the puzzles are not to challenging at all.

- All achievements are optional and very missable requiring a guide to get them. If you don't care about achievements than this shouldn't be a problem

- Although not required, you really need to play this with a controller.

Conclusion

An excellent adventure/puzzle game. The game is more about the journey and the adventure rather than the puzzles. Although short it really was a great experience.

reviewText:
I have over 5000 hours clocked on my Steam account across a variety of genres.

The 3 or so hours I spent playing Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons were some of if not the most captivating and incredible hours I've spent consuming any form of media.

However I look at this game, it blows me away.

The graphics and aesthetics are outstanding. Every area in the game is lovingly crafted for gorgeous views. The animations on the characters are top notch, which is very important because there is no real dialogue in the game - they speak a form of gibberish but through the context, tone of voice, and body language you can generally understand what they're saying.

I'm a heavy book reader, but the story and environment in this game rivals some of my favorite works. The feelings that this game invokes put to rest the debate on whether or not games can truly be an art form.

The gameplay is very novel and innovative and quite fun also. It's not lacking at all in that department - as a puzzle/adventure game, it goes where no other games have gone before and for that alone is worthy of being played.

This may not be my favorite game of all time - I may not be able to sink loads of time into it. I've got thousands of hours in Counter Strike, nearly 700 in Dark Souls, etc. But dammit this is definitely up there, and one of the most important games you can play this generation.

reviewText:
Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is essentially a very story driven experience with some interesting puzzle elements to break up the gameplay. I don't want to say much more than that as the 'game' is very much the experience rather than the gameplay.

The use of the dual analog sticks to control both the Sons independently is a nice twist, and something I'd like to see more of (even if at times it was slightly confusing). In fairness it's only one of the bold decisions the developers made with Brothers, and for me most (if not all) of them worked.
The use of dual analog sticks; the belief in their storytelling being strong enough to not include subtitles to translate the pseudo-langauge they created within the game; and ultiamtely the story you experience.

It's a short review for a short game that lasted just shy of 3 hours in total, and the only thing I can really end this recommendation is:

If you enjoy indie games and the 'Art' experience they often deliver this for you. If you prefer deeper gameplay than this might not be what you're looking for, but it's still a worthwhile purchase for the narrative and platform-puzzle elements it provides.

reviewText:
The game surprised me multiple times along the way - even last seconds of final cutscene.

Right from the beginning it surprises by its visual quality - it is very beautiful, by attention to detail - there are tons of details and tiny cute content you can miss by just running along the path, by its technical quality - very polished and almost flawless.

Later it suprises by original and imaginative world and strange big and little details. And as you get closer to the end it gets more and more gruesome and morbid. Although first it seems like a fantasy game for children, especially due to casual gameplay and visual style, I'm not sure I can recommend a child play it.

Gameplay-wise it is very casual and will not make you replay long sequences or test your hardcore gamer skills. But it's not mindless either. The balance is very precise to make it a game but not allow gameplay overshadow story or visual/audio beauty and immersiveness.

I feel that creators were influenced by many classic games, and weave the influences very organically into the game. There is definitely strong influence from Ico in castle chapters. There is also very deep controller trick reminiscent of Metal Gear's one.

Overall, this game seems perfect labor of love with no visible flaws. Except that in my opinion it's a mature game which can be easily mistaken for a child game, so the target audience will most probably not play it.

Highly recommended.

reviewText: People that know me know that I (perhaps to a fault) have rose tinted glasses when it comes to most things, especially artsy indie-ish things. It pains me to say that, definitively, there is no way in hell this deserves a 90 on metacritic and I felt very misled in my expectations, which is why I feel the need to compensate with a harsh review. While Brothers is a decent enough game, it is not 'Game of the Year' material. Remember, this is the game that BEAT OUT GTA5, Bioshock Infinite and Tomb Raider at the VGX. It boggles the mind.  Any themes it treads have been done much better elsewhere, and the novel puzzling mechanics, while somewhat interesting, are few and far between and often recycled one after another in sequence. I kept waiting for it to heat up, but the big kick never came.\n\nI was led to believe there would be an intensely emotional story, and it was clear that the game was really reaching to provide one. The key ingredient in stories involving loss is that you have a connection to the characters involved. When none of them speak a line of meaningful dialog, that raises the bar significantly and puts the burden on the development of the actors through their actions. A good movie can take us inside the hearts of a fictional character and experience their sense of profound loss within 2 hours. Brothers had three and a half to get the job done, but never bothered to attempt to pick up the slack at all. Any acting done by any of the characters in the game is limited to simple pantomime, or broadly simplistic generalities. There are no facial expressions to appreciate, there are no meaningful challenges of character, there aren't even any gameplay choices that would write in some of the blanks yourself. So to compensate for any true connection to the characters, every 'emotional' scene is accompanied by a haunting soundtrack with string instruments and a lady chanting ehhhhhhhh oooh ehhhhhhhhhh OOOOO"

recommended: but it's the equivalent of the "Applause" sign coming on for an audience and awkward in how hard it tries to manipulate you. It boils down to cartoonish looking characters crying while you sit in your seat feeling embarrassed for the game. I was so very disappointed.\n\nThe mechanic of using both sticks to control each character did shine through in a few instances. reviewText: People that know me know that I (perhaps to a fault) have rose tinted glasses when it comes to most things, especially artsy indie-ish things. It pains me to say that, definitively, there is no way in hell this deserves a 90 on metacritic and I felt very misled in my expectations, which is why I feel the need to compensate with a harsh review. While Brothers is a decent enough game, it is not 'Game of the Year' material. Remember, this is the game that BEAT OUT GTA5, Bioshock Infinite and Tomb Raider at the VGX. It boggles the mind.  Any themes it treads have been done much better elsewhere, and the novel puzzling mechanics, while somewhat interesting, are few and far between and often recycled one after another in sequence. I kept waiting for it to heat up, but the big kick never came.\n\nI was led to believe there would be an intensely emotional story, and it was clear that the game was really reaching to provide one. The key ingredient in stories involving loss is that you have a connection to the characters involved. When none of them speak a line of meaningful dialog, that raises the bar significantly and puts the burden on the development of the actors through their actions. A good movie can take us inside the hearts of a fictional character and experience their sense of profound loss within 2 hours. Brothers had three and a half to get the job done, but never bothered to attempt to pick up the slack at all. Any acting done by any of the characters in the game is limited to simple pantomime, or broadly simplistic generalities. There are no facial expressions to appreciate, there are no meaningful challenges of character, there aren't even any gameplay choices that would write in some of the blanks yourself. So to compensate for any true connection to the characters, every 'emotional' scene is accompanied by a haunting soundtrack with string instruments and a lady chanting ehhhhhhhh oooh ehhhhhhhhhh OOOOO"

reviewText:
IntroBrothers - A Tale of Two Sons. This game really touches your heart in many different ways. Before I dive into the specifics of the game, I'll go over the generalities. I'll have a more in-depth review of the ending for the people that have actually completed the game with analysis, themes, meanings, etc.

Story:Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a story based puzzle game. The basic story revolves around two sons and their journey to help their father who has been struck with an illness. The brothers are forced to solve some puzzles guaranteed to make you think and help many different characters along the way. In this short 2-4 hour adventure, the game still managed to make me feel a genuine concern for each and every character introduced along the way. Not many games can really do that.

Controls/Gameplay:The controls are challenging, to say the least. Depending on whether you use a controller or the keyboard, the left joystick and left trigger control the older brother while the right stick and right trigger control the younger brother. Likewise, on the keyboard, WASD will control one of the brothers and the arrow keys will control another, the space bar and ctrl button taking place of the triggers. Despite these being the only controls in the game for movement and action, I found myself constantly confusing myself on which of the brothers I was controlling. This wasn't really a frustration, but it did allow for some amusing points in the game where both brothers would be running into a wall. As for the gameplay, the game pits you against puzzles throughout your adventure. The puzzle difficulty increases as the game progresses, but I wouldn't say that there were any puzzles that will keep you stuck in the game for more than 2 minutes. Many puzzles require the two brothers to use teamwork, leading to some rewarding moments upon completing a puzzle.

Graphics/PresentationThe graphics fit into the games core design and mood very well. Running on the unreal engine, the game runs very smooth and I encountered no significant FPS drops during the game. From being high up in the mountains to running across glacier ice caps, the game looked beautiful throughout. The game won't blow you away compared to games running on the more powerful engines of Battlefield and Crysis, but Brothers does its job very well. The music in this game is also top notch. The music definitely sets the mood and makes the player feel a certain way. Flawless execution there.

Final Thoughts:Even though I find many positives to say for the game, I feel that this kind of game wouldn't be fit for everyone. Although it may seem appealing to many people from reviews and video clips, this game is suited towards a more mature audience. If you are a type of person to play games seeking pure entertainment and wants the game to give you more than you put into it, I recommend you not buy it. I also think that the $15 pricing is a bit too steep. I really wanted to play this game for a while, and I only purchased it after it went on sale for $1.50. If you are willing to pay $15 for a 2-4 hour game, then by all means, do so. I do feel that the developers deserve that much, but the game doesn't give you $15 of content. Instead, it gives you a memorable gaming experience with many things to remember and think back on. This is the type of game that people will complete and spend a lot of time thinking about what just happened. What this game lacks in content it makes up for in memorability.

Final Rating: 9/10 (missing 1 point from length of actual game)

SPOILERS. THIS PORTION IS ANALYSIS FOR PEOPLE THAT HAVE COMPLETED THE GAMEThere will be many people that complete the game and do not see it as I do. However, the ending is a lot more dense then what you actually play through. If you put yourself in the shoes of the younger brother, the game does feel a lot more harder to bear. Your older brother just died. Throughout the whole game, you and your older brother were inseparable. If you went too far off, you would stop and you would call your older brother over. If your older brother went too far off, he would stop and call you over. If there was something that you couldn't do, you could do it with the help of your older brother. Your flaws in strength and inability to swim are gone with the help of your brother. If you couldn't reach something, your brother was there to boost you up. You became perfect. Unstoppable. With your brother by your side, nothing could go wrong. But now, he's dead.

You aren't immortal. Your flaws are back. If something goes wrong, you don't have your older brother to turn to. Not only that, you have to dig a grave for your brother and then bury him with your own hands. If you didn't think about this during your first playthrough, I suggest you replay that portion of the game and think about this. Upon burying your brother, you are taken back to your hometown. But you aren't taken back right away. You fly over the glaciers, through the mountains, past the castle. You are shown all the places that you have been to be able to get the medicine to heal your father. Getting through all these places would not have been possible without your older brother. When you arrive back to your hometown, you come across water. You can't swim, how are you going to get across? Normally, you would press the action button for the younger brother and grab onto the older brother. But this time, you press the action button of the older brother. Your brother's voice echos through your head as you swim for the first time across the lake. You come across a switch that you're too weak to pull. Again, you press the action button for the older brother and manage to pull the switch down. You come across a ledge you can't reach. Once again, you make it up while pressing the action button for the older brother. Using the action button for the older brother makes it seem that you are borrowing the strength of the older brother to do things that you normally couldn't. Keeping his older brother in mind, the younger brother is able to do things he would normally be unable to do in order to complete both of their goals: saving their father. The final cutscene shows the father crying over the older brother's grave, but the younger brother stands in silent mourning. The younger brother knows that even thought his older brother is gone, his voice will be with him and empower him to continue to push himself to do things beyond his own power.

Quick Last ThoughtsThroughout the whole game, the younger brother is seen to have a close connection with the mother. The opening cutscene shows him mourning over his mother's death, midway through the game, the younger brother has a dream about his mother, and at the end of the game, he gets a vision of his mother who influences him to swim across the water. The older brother is seen to have a close connection with the father. After the initial opening cutscene, the older brother comes to the younger brother and asks for help to get their father to the doctor. Midway through the game, the older brother has a flashback to him and the father fishing. At then end of the game, those close connections are gone. It can be implied that the older brother-mother and the younger brother-father weren't as close as  younger-mother older-father. At the end of the game, the older brother is with the mother and the father is with the younger brother. With that, both bonds can become stronger.

Great game. If did not manage to see these connections on your first play through, I suggest going through the ending once more.

reviewText:
Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons likely contains the most human story to be told in a video game for the entire year of 2013. Dialogue is absent from the game entirely; instead, there is a tasteful reliance on visuals and sound to tell the tale, and boy oh boy (no pun intended), is this EVER a tale to be told.

The gameplay consists of moving two brothers simultaneously through a vivid fairytale. The player must use both brothers for problem solving, whether it is action-related, puzzle-related, or even a boss fight. There is no attack button, so donâ€™t expect a hack and slash.

As far as the story goes, what starts out as a typical fairytale progresses into something darkly heartwarming. There should be a bit of real life in every fairytale and this game nails that idea perfectly.

reviewText: Super intelligent game and an emotional masterclass in story telling. Dual Stick controller recommended to make the most of the innovative control system, though there are keyboard controls. I love the way the game uses camera angles to show you just how far you have travelled or how far lies ahead in the unique and gorgeous fantasy world. I picked it up in the 2013 winter sale, but it is well worth the full asking price. Starbreeze are back on form!

reviewText:
Sometimes you want to play a fairy tale, a simple but beautiful story of basic human values, of self-improvement and of what truly matters to everyone. You want to see some adventures of characters, who you can (or want to) relate to. It's an old formula, take some kids and send them for a quest for the sake of the family, on a road where they will face scary monsters and challenges and overcome their fears.

What most prefer to ignore is that fairy tales are pretty gruesome. Someone alwayse dies in those stories, be it an old king or a dragon, and dies in a rather displeasing way. It's not a fairy tale without a pinch of sorrow in it, and not everything is well after the happy end - monsters and kings remain pretty much dead anyways.

With this game I managed to look at Starbreeze studios from a very different point of view. It is a beautiful game with a distinct fairytaleish athmosphere and a bit naive, but touching story.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is not merely a game, it's a masterpiece of modern gaming and storytelling with the use of a made up language. Considering it's a fairly short title (about 3 hours long), which might put some people off it is surprisingly worth it's value. Brothers presents you astonishing visuals along with one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard in a game. Brothers doesn't really tell you a story like most games out there, it shows you the story by using a made up language, as I mentioned above, you are not presented with a certain and linear story but the way each brother interacts and uses body language to express himself gives you a good feeling of what's going on. Another thing I love about this game is how the developers decided to show you that these two brothers are inseparable, you control each one with a different stick on the controller but yet each puzzle or obstacle cannot be exceeded by using a single brother, one brother needs the other in order to survive... Besides this, everything else I have to say is abunch of spoilers and things that would ruin the way you would experience this game for the first time. I have nothing else to say other than, please buy the game, if not by paying full price atleast try to get it once it's on sale (like I did), we need more games like this, I need more games like this. Definitely one of my favourite games of all time, taking the top 1 place on best storytelling for me and bringing The Walking Dead to top 2.

Be amazed by Brothers!

reviewText:
I have to say, Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons had some of the best gameplay elements I've ever seen! It's just like a regular RPG, but as you probably already know, instead of just controlling just one character, or brother, at a time, you control both at the same time. The puzzles that were designed around this gameplay mechanic are awesome and really fun to do, along with the immersing story and well developed atmosphere.

The main plot is set around two brothers, or two sons, that are on a quest to save their father, who is deathly ill. Their mother had drowned previously and the brothers don't want to lose their dad as well, so they set out to find the special liquid from a magical tree, which is the only thing that can save him. There are absolutely no distinguishable words throughout the whole game, apart from some basic instructions on how to control both brothers at the very start, but the story is still super smooth and easy to follow, so the lack of words won't mess up your understanding of whatâ€™s going on. No spoilers here, but the story of the brothers and their â€œadventuresâ€ is really good, you might even cry.

There are enough levels included in the game to make it long enough. It's only around 3-5 hours, but I reckon it's just the right length to keep a story as this one interesting. Every level is a new experience and there are always new things to do, even with the basic controls, (you only use the triggers and thumb sticks). Hang gliding, throwing balls down wells, riding mountain goats and sitting on benches and looking at the view are only some of the things you can do to keep yourself entertained in this amazing game.

So, the real question is, should you buy this game? Absolutely, I guarantee you'll have a great time with it. It's a little short, but don't let that stop you from getting it. There a many memories to be made as you play this.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons, is very possibly one of the best games I've played purely from the point of it's complete self-integration. The gameplay, the narrative, the atmosphere and scenery all add to the overall experience. Whilst not completely original in idea, it is original in execution.

The gameplay done via a controller is nothing short of superb. Both characters are controlled via both directional sticks of a single controller. Whilst it's awkward to get used to at first, I had both brothers running in completely opposite directions on numerous occasions, it adds a co-operative feel to what is essentially a single player game. The mechanics creating and emphasising the co-operation and relationship between the Brothers themselves, as independently controlled but still reliant on the gamer's ambidexterity.

The narrative is subtle yet no less emotional for being so. This is achieved by the importance of showing the audience rather than telling, so the distinct choice to remove dialogue and tell" the story through visual aids (read body language) and integrated cut-scenes of events is nothing short of brilliant. Each interaction and challenge that the two boys overcome leads to greater involvement in their supportive relationship

reviewText:
It wasn't until the latest Steam Summer Sale that I have heard about this game. I bought it for mere 2 euros then, but after playing the game I can assure you that it is even worth the full price.

Throughout my gaming years I have encountered many different games with many different stories, gameplay mechanics, etc. But this game stands out as a unique example of a gaming masterpiece. Why, might you ask yourself?

First, the game tells a story that maybe isn't the most original story ever told before, but the way it presents itself is simply amazing. You will almost instantly develop emotional connection with both of the brothers and it will last till the very last moment of the game. I can count with one hand the number of games that had such an emotional impact on me as this game did.

Second, the mechanics and gameplay are something I've never seen before. The reason Steam warns you that you need a controller to play is because you control both brothers at the same time. It seems tricky, but in reality is very natural and fluid. You will get a hold of it in minutes. I liked the concept.

All things being said, this game is short, but will take you on such emotional rollercoaster in it's 3-4 hours of story that you will never forget.

Must play.

reviewText:
This is my first proper recommendation of a game on Steam. Because no other game that I have ever played has provoked my emotions in a way Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons has.

The story of two brothers against the world, fighting to save their father. A simple story, but the way it is told has to be one of the most breath-taking experiences a video game can muster. I can't say much with regards to the story except that if story-driven games are your thing, you have to play.

Every little aspect of this game, from the game controls to the language spoken by the brothers helps you connect with them, their troubles, their fears, their emotions. No game has so far captivated me this quickly and this deeply, although I am probably feeling this way because I just finished it. And that's just fine. This game is a masterpiece that everyone should experience.

Some brief review notes:
Do not judge the game solely based on the first few minutes of gameplay, as the puzzles and co-operative mechanics develop at an amazing pace. The ideas in the game are innovative, not repetitively used and are a lot of fun to experience.

Controls-wise, this game definitely has to be played with a controller with two joysticks to get the most out of the game. The keyboard controls are manageable but a controller is best. However, there are times where you are required to hold down the buttons for minutes on end which is quite stressful on the fingers.

The graphics and art are nothing special, although some of the scenes do inspire some awe in you. The game isn't about the art however and the deciding factor in whether you want to play a game should almost never be graphical quality.

Brothers makes use of the controller in a way no other game I've played has ever done. That could be my inexperience talking, but the innovative way you control the two brothers using a joystick and shoulder pad each pulls you into the game and doesn't let go. It takes some getting used to of course, but a helpful tip is to try and keep the younger brother on the right as much as possible as it helps coordinate better early on.

The speech in the game is no known language. And this is one of the best features of this game. The story does not rely on voice acting or script, but the true weight and emotion of the story itself as well as the body language and gestures of the characters. Very few games have managed to pull this off to the degree that Brothers has and I fear no other would be able to live up to this quality of story for a long time.

Puzzle platformer games are nothing new. Many games have a tried and tested formula to them. Brothers on the other hand is a game that no other game would make you go: Oh

reviewText:
Personal Rating: 9/10

An emotional adventure not as aesthetically unique as Journey and not as powerful as The Last of Us, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons lies somewhere in between. It is above all a story told with no more than pseudowords and names (I'm thinking it's not really a conlang they speak) and an accurate soundtrack that fits perfectly with each sequence. The plot itself is rather simple. Two brothers must save their father who is terribly ill. For that they have to reach the Tree of Life and harvest the water that springs from its center. A lot happens, and I can just say that the whole journey is unforgettable.

The whole artwork and design is at times reminiscent of Shadow of the Colossus and ICO, in which the player journeys into and out of the dreamlike â€œForbidden Landsâ€. The very concept of travel, journey and quest is essential to the whole atmosphere of both games, and it works the same way in Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons. (Also, one can see how the couple's escape in ICO and the wanderer's quest to save his loved one in SotC might have influenced Starbreeze.)

As to gameplay, the controls feel very awkward at first, and even by the end of the game I still struggled here and there. But they never get to the point of breaking immersion. On the contrary: for me playing this game feels exactly as it should â€” you must control both brothers simultaneously rather than alternating between the two as is commonly done. This is especially effective in one particular chapter, in a way which I wonâ€™t comment in order to avoid spoilers.

Though the game is short, I strongly recommend it for anyone interested in the  style  of game I vaguely call â€œan experienceâ€. Indeed, unless you are too impatient with unconventional, inventive controls (in which case you will hate this game), I say this game is definitely worth a try.

reviewText:
Simply brilliant adventure-story telling game.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons offers a unique experience of its own and delivers it thru incredible graphic details. When you journey, you'll see the intrinsically beautiful game world and level designs. The OSTs just add more to the awesomeness, so atmospheric and fitting.

Gameplay is quite simple as you only need to move around and solve simple puzzles. There's a bit annoying boss battles but it's nothing anyway if you play many more of challenging games nowadays like Bastion. Though, really, the major strength of the game lies not in its gameplay but in its storyline - despite the voice actors speak in made-up language (no English caption sorry!), it can convey the story with the body language and display. Following the story is also another great experience. You'll see the value of your sibling, or brotherhood, through how the two brothers here work together and lend a hand to to each others. Sometimes we forget about that siblings are wonderful gift, eh?

Checkpoints are scattered throughout the game so suppose you die from accidental glitches - yes, happened to me - or die in boss battles you don't have to retrack your steps too far. The game offers chapter to chapter selection so you can easily replay the chapter you want to rewatch.

While the controller is recommended (xinput based works flawlessly while dinput requires x360ce to play), you can also use keyboard to play the game. Heck, you can coop using gamepad for first player and keyboard for the second player, though it's a bit awkward to play coop in a game like this. That said, controlling two brothers using gamepad, which is recommended, can be a bit awkward at first as usually we use the right stick to aim or shoot not to move.

If you want to have a perfect achievements, it's not hard. Basically everything can be done in one playthrough - and that also makes the game quite limited in replayability. zero reason to replay the game unless you just want to remember the story.

I myself got this from Amazon with Editor's Choice Coupon 2014 enabled, around 2.5 USD in total. At this price, it's a bargain. Paying full price is, for me, rather not recommended as the game's too short. You can finish the game in one sitting, 4 hours total gameplay. 5 hours if you backtrack to get the achievements you missed.

But overall, an excellent game to be added to your library AND to be played. Believe me, it's a good game right from the concept, storyline and implementation. Looking forward to the next game of Starbreeze Studios AB.

reviewText:
It's not often I care much about the graphics of a game - being a Nintendo gamer and all, gameplay often comes first (as it should). But this game? This game has changed my opinion.

Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons has such a beautiful art style, like Fable: that realistic yet slightly cartoony look. The game is filled with an array of warm colours, gorgeous lighting and an absolutely HUGE sense of scale. Playing as the two brothers in such a lonely yet amazing set of environments, you feel absolutely dwarfed by the sheer scale of it all. This is saying a lot - but I'm going as far as to say this visually looks more impressive than Okami, which if you've played you'll know is one of the best looking games despite its age.

Coupled with a superb, chilling soundtrack and a completely unique single-player co-op gameplay style; this is seriously the perfect game. Two hours in and I swear this is game of the year material, if not one of the best games I've ever played if it continues the way it's started.

This had better win a multitude of indie game awards. People NEED to play this.

taking part of.

The gameplay is special, creative and fun. I will note tho,
that a game controller IS required to play this game, and I
will explain why. In this game you control both of the two
brothers at the same time, the way they did this was dedicating
one of the two analog sticks to each of the brothers and one
shoulder button to each of the brothers. With the left analog stick
and shoulder button you control the eldest brother, and with the
right analog stick and shoulder button you control the youngest.

This is a really fun and creative way to do this, and often brings
orientation difficulty during some situations. When the two brothers
cross over to the opposite side of the screen from each other,
the control sheme stays the same, so the controls in a way
becomes inverted. It's a fun challenge and I found myself
during some situations just stopping up to get my orientation stright.

The game combines this special control aspect of the game with
some intriguing puzzles, which will require some multitasking.
None of the puzzles is especially hard to do, but they were fun
and creative. Tho because the game developers went for the choise
of giving this world an imaginary language, and not specially
much written text at all, there were a few situations I was lost
as of what I was supposed to do, but not for long.

As for the story in this game, it's really good. You'll get immersed
in this world and continue adventuring to try finding a cure for
your dying father. You'll encounter some really dark situations in
this game, dark emotional situations, some of the situations
you encounter might get to you and make you just think over
what just happened. It's not a tale of happy rainbows and chocolate,
it's a mature journey which will bring up subjects like death, suicide
and the strong bond between two brothers.

I spent approximately 3.1 hours completing this game, so it's not
especially long, and because this game really doesn't
bring much replay-value into it, I find the price tag of 14â‚¬ to
be a tiny bit too much, to be honest. But, this is an exceptionally
beautiful and mature tale of two brothers, in one of the prettiest
game worlds I've seen, so the 14â‚¬'s was worth it.

because of short game time
and little to none replay-value.

reviewText:
It has been a very long time since a game managed to make me cry... this one had me sobbing.

Prepare yourself for this emotional rollercoaster - this game is both as beautiful and atmospheric as it is heartwrenching. Having just lost their mother to drowning at sea, and now on the verge of losing their gravely ill father, the two titular brothers set off on a surreal journey to obtain the one thing able to cure him. The story unfolds without words (at least, not words that are comprehensible), using body language, music and nuance in a manner that is masterfully handled and pulls you straight in.

Gameplay, unfortunately, is where Brothers suffers. Firstly, you NEED to use an Xbox 360 controller. Each brother is controlled individually with each control stick, proving to have a steep learning curve. This essentially gives an illusion of co-op, which while visually interesting and making both of their movements feel organic (rather than an NPC programmed to follow you), it proves to be quite frustrating at first as you frequently lose track of which stick controls which brother. Another downside is that it's also quite short and can be finished in only a few hours.

Atmosphere, story and visuals are this game's bread and butter. Despite the frustrating gameplay, if you're fond of games strong on story that tug at your heartstrings and leave you thinking long after the credits have rolled, I can't recommend this highly enough.

reviewText:
It's not often I care much about the graphics of a game - being a Nintendo gamer and all, gameplay often comes first (as it should). But this game? This game has changed my opinion.

Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons has such a beautiful art style, like Fable: that realistic yet slightly cartoony look. The game is filled with an array of warm colours, gorgeous lighting and an absolutely HUGE sense of scale. Playing as the two brothers in such a lonely yet amazing set of environments, you feel absolutely dwarfed by the sheer scale of it all. This is saying a lot - but I'm going as far as to say this visually looks more impressive than Okami, which if you've played you'll know is one of the best looking games despite its age.

Coupled with a superb, chilling soundtrack and a completely unique single-player co-op gameplay style; this is seriously the perfect game. Two hours in and I swear this is game of the year material, if not one of the best games I've ever played if it continues the way it's started.

This had better win a multitude of indie game awards. People NEED to play this.
