reviewText:
Quite an enjoyable game with a very moving story told in a unique way.

Firstly, you *need* a twin stick controller to play this - you *might* be able to kludge your way through with the keyboard, but you really don't want to. If you don't have one, go in to the City and buy an XBox 360 controller right now - I'll wait.... OK, you have one? Good.

Now, I love a game with a good story, but let's be honest - in most games the story and gameplay are somewhat disconnected from each other and could just as easily be presented as two separate pieces of art. Heck, there are some games that would have done better to throw away one (or two!) of those pieces altogether!

This game is different - the story and the gameplay are both perfectly intertwined. Sure, it still has cutscenes, but the story is largely conveyed while you control the brothers throughout their journey. This game has managed to figure out how to use the unique properties of a video game to tell it's story, rather than relying on techniques from movies or novels like every other game.

There is also, no speach - well, at least not English. The characters do use body language and speak some kind of made up language to effectively convey emotion and meaning, without distracting from the story or journey at hand. A gamepad is a must for this game, each thumb stick controls one of the brothers, while the corresponding trigger causes each brother to take action. The scheme works much better than I thought it would, rarely did controlling each brother at the same time feel cumbersome and after some practice it felt natural.\nVisually the game is very pretty, you will explore different scenery like mountains and ice, and come face to face with a vast array of NPCâ€™s in the form of animals, giants, ferries and a host of others.  The sound is appropriate to the fantasy setting, the characters speak in a made up language, so most of the story is told thru gestures and the visuals along with the musical score, it all works together to give the gaming world a unique feeling of life.  Itâ€™s a short game, clocking in at 4 hours or so, but its just long enough to feel like you went on an adventure without getting repetitive.  Brothers is imaginative, not very violent & will challenge your brain just enough to feel like you accomplished something without frustrating you, very balanced and enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
This game is easily my game of the year for 2013. What first looked to me like a small-time indie game that probably wasn't worth my time ended up being one of the most phenomenal titles I've ever played.

This game tells an engaging story without a single word of spoken English; characters speak complete gibberish yet still convey emotion incredibly. It's only a 2.5-3 hour experience but it doesn't need to be any longer, it's the perfect length to finish in a single sitting and you will never feel that it has outstayed its welcome. The level and puzzle design is perfectly done, you should never need to think overly hard and you should always have a good idea of where you're meant to be going and what you're meant to be doing.

Graphically the game really holds its own. I can see this title being one of those timeless games that never quite looks outdated visually; it's bright, colorful and charming. It should also be noted that the control system is unusual but not bad at all, you control each brother with a separate analog stick and bumper and it works perfectly that way. Also, that's me recommending that you play this game with a gamepad, the keyboard controls work but are nowhere near as comfortable.

If you have any taste in games at all you should purchase this game, lock yourself away from any distractions, pick up your gamepad and play through this game in a single sitting. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
In this day and age, I find myself increasingly frustrated and fed up with the video game industry. Maybe it's the 'ship it unfinished and patch it later' mentality, anti-consumer drm, emphasis on pre-orders with exclusive bonuses, big publishers inability to push anything that isn't a AAA military shooter, micro-transactions, you name it. I find it hard to excited about upcoming titles, and even developers that I previously thought could do no wrong (Blizzard, Bethesda, Bioware, Dice etc) are all dropping the ball in big ways. All of this makes finding a gem like this title all the more appealing.

Brothers is an adventure game in which you control two characters at the same time, using both sides of your controller. This immediately makes the game feel fresh - it's almost like playing a coop game with yourself as a partner. It feels weird initially, but it works, and immediately builds a bond with both characters and the player. The controls are tight and movement is fluid and smoothly animated. Graphically, the game is stunning. While not being incredible on a technical level, it combines solid visual quality with a striking, memorable art style that creates a truly immersive and beautiful world. The landscapes are richly detailed and often have a story behind them that you can pick up if you pay attention. The environments are varied and it has an incredible sense of scale that almost reminds me of the God of War games (not that this is a button mashing gore fest, but it has that enormous scope that can make you feel very very insignificant).

The characters are memorable, both the brothers and the individuals you meet along the way are loaded with personality, the animation is fluent and they are all wonderfully unique. Interestingly, not a word of English is spoken, but the expressiveness of the voice acting and the animation mean that you understand everything that is happening perfectly. The music is also memorable, the instrumentation is striking and I love the use of space and silence in the score.

Initially, the only negative I could think of was the length of the game. I finished it in around 3 hours, and I took my time. I have since changed my mind - I feel that the story being told would have started to drag if it went on significantly over that, and although I wish I could play it more, the amount of gameplay they pack in is fantastic. The areas are varied and interesting, the puzzles and platforming are challenging enough so that you have to pay attention, but never so hard that you get stuck. I was initially going to write about some of the many unique moments that are part of this game, but they are probably best experienced first hand. Definately some suprise moments.

Brothers has reminded me of why I love this medium. I cannot recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
First things first: you'll want an Xbox controller or equivalent. Keyboard controls are available, but a recurring puzzle in the game requires you to rotate both control sticks which for obvious reasons becomes a major pain when you aren't using a controller.

Overall, I enjoyed this game. It's the closest thing a game can get to being a movie without ceasing to be a game, and it's done quite well. The storyline's very well-written and executed, and the graphics are similarly good and styled in just the right way to boost your immersion into the story (most of the time). The controls are solid, the camera generally does its job (except when you're shimmying on top of a narrow ledge) and the puzzles are intuitive.

That's not to say there aren't flaws. The graphics, being generally good, only ended up killing my immersion on the occasions they weren't; examples include a flock of 2D bats in the glider section and footprints that appeared everywhere but where I was actualy stepping in the snowy area.

Since this is a heavily story-driven game, it's linear and fairly short (still more than twice as long as your average movie, though). If there's a side path, it either joins up with the main path within a short amount of time or exists solely to provide an achievement. It's usually pretty obvious what you're supposed to do, so there isn't a whole lot of challenge to the game; if you're the kind of gamer who can't stand games that don't kill you for breathing too hard, I wouldn't pick this game up.

The few times it isn't clear what you need to do end up extremely grating by contrast; two of these particularly got on my nerves. First, there's a glider segment where your glider gets torn apart , and aiming at the nearest landmass ends up getting you killed and makes you do the entire (2 minute) glider section all over again. Second, near the end of the game there's a segment where you have to get Little Bro (who can't swim) across a body of water while Big Bro isn't close enough to help; to find the solution, you literally have to mash buttons.

I also encountered several glitches, many of which forced me to restart from a checkpoint; feel free to check out my screenshot gallery for examples. (And one spoiler, though it's properly tagged.) Fortunately, they didn't happen more than once per location, and were very infrequent.

Despite these flaws, I found that the game was enjoyable and worth its $5 price tag, especially since I approached the game from the perspective of it being an interactive movie.

reviewText:
Brothers really is fantastic and one of the stand out games of 2013.

Itâ€™s an adventure set in a fairy tale world that flows evocatively between moments of whimsy and tragedy.   Itâ€™s a coming of age tale, itâ€™s about bonds and friendship and loss, it is a modern Ico, conceptually simple yet beautifully crafted.

You control two brothers simultaneously, each half of the controller moving one of the siblings. Interaction with the world is simple, thereâ€™s only one interaction button for each boy and there are no menus or magic or combat. Controlling each individual character is simple, but coordinating their actions in order to transverse their world is somewhat akin to trying to pat your head while rubbing your stomach.

Thatâ€™s not to say the game is difficult. While there are puzzles to solve, thereâ€™s little in the way of real challenge. But the game isnâ€™t about that, itâ€™s not about getting a high score or finding collectable items. Itâ€™s a story waiting to be told and every interaction tells part of the story.

The game is essentially wordless, with a simlish like language used. Instead the story is told through the animation. As the two brothers interact with the same object their personality comes through, the care free nature of the youngest brother and the older one trying to be strong and responsible while still being a teenager.

The game is only a couple of hours longs, but itâ€™s very lean and takes you on quite a journey in in that time. Itâ€™s also a remarkably pretty game with a lovely soundtrack. Thereâ€™s plenty more that can be told about Brothers but itâ€™s really a game that deserves to be experienced.

reviewText:
Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons

---ABOUT---

In this Indie-Action-Adventure we follow the story of
two brothers, whom recently lost their mother in
a tragic accident. And now they are faced with a new
alarming situation, their father is ill and will soon die.

The two brothers sets out on a adventure to recover
a magic three juice that will save their father.

---REVIEW---

To start of, this is one of the prettiest indie games
I have ever played. The graphics and art design is
really outstanding, and I found myself stopping up
for a brief period of time to just look at the
scenery. Some of the scenery just left me in awe,
it's a really unique world and the graphical style
from the landscape to the creatures in this game
is really wonderful.

The world in this game is truly stunning.

The audio is also getting a huge thumbs up from me.
A huge variety of fantastic sound effects and a
soundtrack which really fits inn with the situations
you encounter in this game and the world we're
taking part of.

The gameplay is special, creative and fun. I will note tho,
that a game controller IS required to play this game, and I
will explain why. In this game you control both of the two
brothers at the same time, the way they did this was dedicating
one of the two analog sticks to each of the brothers and one
shoulder button to each of the brothers. With the left analog stick
and shoulder button you control the eldest brother, and with the
right analog stick and shoulder button you control the youngest.

This is a really fun and creative way to do this, and often brings
orientation difficulty during some situations. When the two brothers
cross over to the opposite side of the screen from each other,
the control sheme stays the same, so the controls in a way
becomes inverted. It's a fun challenge and I found myself
during some situations just stopping up to get my orientation stright.

The game combines this special control aspect of the game with
some intriguing puzzles, which will require some multitasking.
None of the puzzles is especially hard to do, but they were fun
and creative. Tho because the game developers went for the choise
of giving this world an imaginary language, and not specially
much written text at all, there were a few situations I was lost
as of what I was supposed to do, but not for long.

As for the story in this game, it's really good. You'll get immersed
in this world and continue adventuring to try finding a cure for
your dying father. You'll encounter some really dark situations in
this game, dark emotional situations, some of the situations
you encounter might get to you and make you just think over
what just happened. It's not a tale of happy rainbows and chocolate,
it's a mature journey which will bring up subjects like death, suicide
and the strong bond between two brothers.

I spent approximately 3.1 hours completing this game, so it's not
especially long, and because this game really doesn't
bring much replay-value into it, I find the price tag of 14â‚¬ to
be a tiny bit too much, to be honest. But, this is an exceptionally
beautiful and mature tale of two brothers, in one of the prettiest
game worlds I've seen, so the 14â‚¬'s was worth it.

---SCORE---

I will pull some points off from Value"
date:
because of short game time
and little to none replay-value.

Graphics: 9.5/10
Audio: 9.0/10
Gameplay: 9.0/10
Story: 9.0/10
Value: 7.0/10

Score: 8.7/10"

reviewText:
Good:
Stellar graphics
Unique gameplay
Beautiful story
Soothing score
Pacing

Bad:
Not keyboard-friendly
Short

Summary:
From the dev team that brought us games like The Darkness, Chronicles of Riddick, and Syndicate, Starbreeze Studios have tried something refreshing and much appreciated. Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons keeps the narrative-driven gaming trend going this year with relateable interactions and development in an unforgettable journey.

The game starts off showing a flashback of the mother of the two sons' death. Whilst reminiscing on that tragic day, the two brothers' father falls ill. After a trip to the local doctor, the brothers are told about the water from the 'tree of life' which appears to be the only way to save their dad, and so their quest begins.

Right off the bat the visuals are phenomenal, making use of the Unreal Engine 3. Vibrant colors shown in various settings such as forests, mountains, dungeons, and small towns, nice cell-shading style, detailed shadows...for an indie-style game, it actually looks on par or even better than some AAA titles. To top it off, the soundtrack sets the tone and brings the world to life, immerseful and always in the back of your mind whilst playing (see video at the top to get an idea).

The controls are unlike any I've played before it. You control two characters simultaneously, and whilst there's very few controls to use (movement for either side of analogs, and one button interaction for each brother), how they integrated and executed the controls is brilliant. It takes some getting used to, and you'd tend to forget a finger on a button here or there whilst trying to keep the brothers on track with their mission, but the game isn't punishing. It's simplistic and overall not too difficult to play. The two brothers rely on one another to move forward, both having significant differences to get through various puzzles. However, playing with a keyboard can prove to be frustrating. Definitely recommend a controller (even the Steam page claims it requires a controller to play, although keyboard controls are available).

There is never a dull moment in this game. The pacing is perfect. For such simple mechanics with the unique twist of controlling two characters at once, each segment, or well, chapter, is different and utilizes the innovative controls in a variety of ways. And the best part about the pacing is, and this is a debatable point, the simple puzzles keep the game from detouring and ruining its experience.

Whilst the gameplay and graphics are integral, very fun parts of the game, what outshines more than anything, what brings all the elements together and shapes it into an extraordinary game, is the growth of the brothers. They have to go through hell and high water in order to save their father, and like any group of siblings stuck together for so long, there's going to be rivalry. Their age and clothing show their typical, rather cliche attitudes well, and we need that to piece their styles together as there's no English in this game. There's voice-acting, but done in a fake language allowing us to detail the characters on our own. The brothers encounter various people and things to interact with, with both reacting their on way to any given situation, further drawing their different personalities to us.

Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is an emotional ride. It doesn't just stop with the engaging, roller coaster of a story, it is a well-rounded game with fun controls and beautiful graphics to follow suit. It shows us very, very strong bonds as children, as siblings, as a family...life lessons secretly hidden in this title. This, along with Gone Home, have really set a new mark in gaming today, pushing forward for the better of the industry. And now...I urge anyone who stuck around reading this to try it. We need more games like Brothers. These titles are taking risks and evolving the gaming industry, or have the possibility to, so long as they get more exposure. And even without talking about it, the experience itself is worth the price of admission. A general $15 full retail price for a 3-4 hour game, but there's constant sales and even if you don't catch it during a sale it's still very much worth it. Couldn't recommend Brothers enough. Thank you for reading.

reviewText:
This is an intense experience, albeit a short one.

The journey leads you through a quite surrealistic fantasy world which fluctuates between being joyful and depressing, though it clearly drifts towards the latter over the course of the game. There's not that much of a plot actually and as there is neither any on-screen text, nor any spoken language other than the unintelligible fantasy language the characters are using every now and then, the main focus clearly is the emotional impact rather than the actual plot. This is working great, though.

This cannot unconditionally be said about the controls, however. Controlling two characters at once with an actually very basic setup (using one analogue stick and one trigger per character, plus two buttons for camera control) is an interesting concept and nicely supports the narrative in certain ways, but it's really easy to get confused, especially in sections demanding that both brothers are simultaneously moved more or less precisely. You can certainly get used to it, but it might take a while and the game might actually already be over at that point ;)

You can easily plow through the game in three hours or probably even less. There's some replay value because of several optional parts - in fact, all of the game's achievements are completely optional. Then again, not each achievement is unlocked by an additional puzzle of some sorts, but sometimes simply by interacting with the right object long enough. The puzzles in general might be a bit too easy and for the most part they rather test your patience than your logical thinking. Pretty much all of them make great sense in the context of the journey, though - there's no tacked-on riddle solving that feels out of place.

All in all this game does indeed deserve the praise it's been getting ever since its release, and it is very easy to ignore the lack of challenge and the basic nature of the plot as it still delivers some satisfying gameplay and an emotionally impactful and visually beautiful experience.

For comparable titles, see Journey (PS3), Papo y Yo, and maybe Limbo.

reviewText:
Everyone knows and most have their constantly growing - especially after a big sale - tower of 'games to play in the future' here on Steam. Most of these games will never be played at all, but sometimes there is a little gem, where you ask yourself, why you waited so long to find it.

After a long time I decided to give this game a try, that promotes itself with a very unique co-op gameplay with one controller. Being not that much of a fan of controller based games I was impressed how very well this game uses this advertised feature. After getting that small barrier (for me) out of the way, a very good story (for a 'puzzle platformer') presented in a graphical wonderful world awaited me.

The puzzles and platforming parts aren't hard at all, so it is possible to fluently play through this game without getting stuck. Every chapter holds some little secrets, so it encourages you to explore the small world a bit.

So if you are not afraid of multitask two players on one controller by yourself, then grab that game.

reviewText:
Very inventive controls and really great worldbuilding. The environments were all really beautiful and interesting and the way you move through them was surprising throughout.

I wasn't as emotionally invested as some people seem to have been, but the story works nonetheless and the controls and environments were enough to leave me with a very positive impression of the game. The game becomes increasingly surreal as you progress through it, and it made the world this takes place in really interesting. I would absolutely love to get more background information about some of the things I saw in the game.

The great thing is that the game doesn't tell you anything through text or dialogue. The dialogue that's there is all in a made-up language, and there's nothing to read. Instead, the game SHOWS everything and it does a very good job at that. Everything is clear enough to get from A to B and solve the puzzles without many problems, but vague enough to remain mysterious.

The controls are also a pretty good point about the game. A controller is basically a must. Each brother is controlled by one of the analogue sticks, and each has an interact-button. You control both brothers at the same time, and... it just works really well. All the puzzles are easy enough to grasp within a few seconds but still require some finesse to get right. Even so, the game isn't really about the puzzles so much as about the story and the two brothers from the title.

The game takes about 3 hours to complete, perhaps a bit longer if you try to get all the achievements, which are basically just tiny extra bits of story that can be really good in their own right.

I would definitely recommend this. It's not a game you can sink countless hours in, but it's definitely worth the trouble of picking up and playing through at least once.

reviewText:
What a wonderful game!

A story telling the journey two brothers undertake to find a cure for their seriously ill father. You control both brothers simultaneously, having to help each other to overcome the many obsticles they encounter.

The puzzles can tax your co-ordination, as you try and maneuver the brothers into position and interacting with the correct one - but don't let this deter you; this game is telling you their story and the puzzles are just there to give you the sense of the struggles they come across.

The sounds in the game are simplistic, but they work perfectly to set the atmosphere - the game doesn't even need dialogue, the actions of the characters and the random noises they make say all that needs saying to let you understand what is going on and what you need to do.

The graphics in the game are beautiful. The art-style I would say is in the same vein as Fable, which again suits it just right, and will leave you wide-eyed at the various environments the brothers must progress through on their journey.

The game may be short, but it is an experience you need in gaming. I highly recommend this!

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a beautiful top-down puzzle adventure developed by Swedish developer Starbreeze Studios, who are better known for rather action-heavy games such as Riddick, The Darkness, Syndicate or Payback, so it's definitely a surprise that their first non-shooter game ended up being such a lovingly crafted piece of work.

The game tells the moving story of two brothers who set out on a journey across the lands to find a cure for their ailing father. While this is a pretty average story, it is presented with so much strength and emotion that it is really hard not to get touched by it. Even more so due the fact that there is no 'real' voice acting in the game apart from bits and pieces in a made-up language, so every bit of feeling and emotion the game tries to convey is is entirely transported through the fantastic soundtrack, the level design and the character acting.

Although the game is based on the PC-friendly Unreal Engine, it doesn't really provide many graphics options aside from brightness, resolution and VSync, but that shouldn't hold you off because the game looks absolutely stunning regardless.

The level design is fairly linear, so there is usually just one path to get from A to B, but the varying enviroments are packed with so much detail and love that it is a real pleasure to the eye to just wander around and explore all the tiny details Starbreeze has left in the game, such as a squirrel climbing a tree or bunnies hopping around. You can also sit down on any of the various benches in the levels to get a scenic view of some special spots. Absolutely fantastic.

An innovation that I haven't seen in any other game yet are the gameplay mechanics as you control both brothers at once, each brother with one thumb stick on your control, so it's basically like playing a two-player co-op game - but alone. This feels extremely weird at first and will definitely put your coordination and multitasking skills to the test, but the further you get into the game the more you get used to it.

The puzzles in the game make use of this mechanic in various ways and while the puzzle solutions as such generally are fairly obvious, solving them by controlling both brothers at once provides the actual challenge.

PSA: Despite the fact that the store page mentions 'Notice: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons requires a controller to play', the game can be played with a keyboard just fine and the launcher also lets you rebind the keys (by default you control one brother with WASD and the other one with the arrow keys). I definitely recommend playing the game with a controller, though, as this simply feels better with a game like this.

With roughly 3.5 to 4 hours the game isn't exceptionally long by most people's standard, but it has so much depth and emotion that I consider it worth it every single cent if it manages to leave me with both sadness and satisfaction upon finishing it. If I had known what a strong game this is, I wouldn't have hesitated to pre-order it.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a shiny gem among the games released this year and needs all the attention it can get. Especially these days where games rarely tell such an emotional story - or any story at all.

reviewText:
A story about how the boy Naiee grows up under the brotherhood of Naia.  The game is unique in that the language spoken is frictional and the players are free to speculate what the characters in the game talk about.  The game's control is divided between the two brothers (LS + LT for Naia, RS + RT for Naiee).  Playing the game encourages you to coordinate between your left and right hands.

The scenic and music are both beautiful.  For people with beefy hardware, I encourage you render the game in 4k and see the beauty yourself.

The journey ahead of the two brothers is by no mean smooth or without loss.  Often it's when people lose things that they start to realize how precious these things are.  [10/10]

reviewText:
As it stands right now, I was able to beat Brothers in less than 3 and a half hours. A game has to be REALLY REALLY good to be that short and still hold a reccomendation from me at a market price of 15 dollars, but yet here I am, with two thumbs up for this artistic masterpiece of a game. From a gameplay standpoint, Brothers is quite simple at the basic level - no puzzles were too advanced and the platforming is simple and doesn't require any button presses. Where the golden mechanic lies is the fact that you control the brothers simultaneously, a feat achieved by assigning a brother to one stick of a joypad (which is mandatory for play). While disorienting at first, eventually you pick up the pace and find it an enjoyable and innovative mechanic to work cooperatively with... yourself. Very ingenious.

But where the game lacks in length and puzzles, it REEAAAALLLY picks up in atmosphere, visuals, and story. To begin, the story is just that two sons are finding a liquid that will restore their sick dad's health, by following a map. Yeah, not much there, but it's interesting in that the entire story is conveyed without a single line of dialouge, but rather with hand gestures and the context of the envrionment. What I find best about the atmosphere is that it is beautiful, one of the most beautiful platofrmers since Trine 2 (which I found really enticing). I found myself staring at the villages, dark forests, snowy mountaintops, and rainy rivers simply for their aesthetic value, not really for their gameplay. The atmosphere is only further enhanced by a somber and dramatic soundtrack, which always accomponies the narrative in a guiding way and really caps off the sad ending.

Overall, I'd recomend it if you are in the mood for a short but magnificently beautiful work of art, perhaps one of the most mature video games on the market as we speak.

reviewText:
Perfect game.

I enjoyed every minute of this. I was drawn into the world and the story completely while I played. I felt like I was on an epic adventure, and I was truly invested into the 3 main characters. Now that I'm finished I can appreciate things in finer detail.

Gameplay is certainly unique, but that's not the main take-away here. I think -everything- comes together to make a truly memorable experience.

The unique gameplay mechanic (driving both brothers with one controller) is certainly notable and memorable by itself, and something else will use this mechanic in the future and I'll think of this game. But that doesn't give the full picture. The atmosphere created by the design and the music and the story all- is a new benchmark for me. I'm sure I'll think of it often.

You can run through this world, taking the shortest path to your goal, and enjoy yourself thoroughly I think. But you don't have to. Despite the epic adventure vibe, you're not at all rushed, and you can stop to smell the roses of this wonderful environment (and you get an achievement for doing so). There are other characters in the world that you pass in your travels, and you can often play some part in their lives. Looking at the achievments screen now that I'm done reveals that I missed some of this myself, but I don't feel like I missed anything really.

I was emotionally spent after completing this game. I took a lot from the experience and that might stick with me longest. As an experience, I think it rates with the best movies I've ever seen. I don't usually get this quality from games, and that probably intensified it for me, but it's excellent to be sure. I took some minutes to bask in it after I was done.

It's not a difficult game, although the very first time you come across a new puzzle aspect (particularly at the start of the game) you will be confused until you get it, I think that as a whole, that aspect was good for the game. It doesn't take long to pick up really.

Find some quiet hours and throw yourself into this game completely and you ought to get twice as much out of it.

reviewText:
By far one of the most immersive, emotional experiences i've ever had in a video-game. The gameplay while odd at first, is definitely intuitive that adds to the overall experience, the puzzles are challenging and garner a sense of accomplishment upon completion. Though the game lacks any real dialogue (aside from gibberish and hand gestures) the story is an emotional roller-coaster that perfectly blends the two mediums of gameplay and story-telling that leaves a mark when the credits are rolling, I felt that this is one of the very few games that created a real emotional connection.

Before you say anything, no this isn't like The Walking Dead or Limbo, games that have recieved a large amount of backlash in the sense that they're not real games, but interactive stories, that is not the case with Brothers. You live the story, you don't sit back and watch thirty minutes of cutscenes with a little bit of game-play in between, a great example of this without spoiling anything, is towards the final act of the game. A scenario which could've easily been shown through a cutscene is instead fully playable, you live out this moment which undeniably leaves a major impact. I've never written a review on Steam before, but after completing this game I was compelled.The game possesses a beautiful  art style that brings out a wonderful yet dark world complemented by a soundtrack that gave a sense of 'awe' that fully captured and immeresed me in these brother's journey.

Without a doubt the best $3 i've ever spent I can't reccomend this game enough, grab it while it's cheap. The game will take you around three hours to complete (which is a perfect length for this title) and I reccommend you finish it in one sitting. Lock your doors, switch off your phone, and enjoy the masterpiece that is Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons".

P.S. Play with a controller
date: this game was definitely made for it."

reviewText:
*me screaming at game* HOW COULD YOU DO THIS TO ME?

*ahem*

Okay, let me give this game a more satisfactory review.

(Mild spoilers below)

When I was a film student in college, my film professor loved hammering in this idea to his students: sound is everything. And lack thereof. He prefers silent films for this reason: visual storytelling should not rely on sound to create the story. Sound should be a suppliment to that story, not a crutch. And, when done right, the right sound effects in the right place can drastically heighten emotional impact.

Good sound design is one of those things that often goes unnoticed in film and game critique. And Brothers has good sound design.

The lack of understandable dialogue actually makes the story better because it forces us to discern the story from simple action alone. Oftentimes I found myself rationalizing the actions of the brothers and other NPCs by determining their emotions from their actions. Such as the crying forest giant- context allowed me to discern that someone he loved was gone. That was just one example of many I found myself thinking as I played the game. Don't give your audience 4: give them 2+2. Let them figure it out. That's why this game doesn't need dialogue.

The music only has a discernable melody and composition when in emotionally intense situations. Otherwise, it is atmospheric, indecipherable sounds. This is effective because if a musician relies too much on bombarding our senses with fantastic melodies at all times, we will not be able to appreciate a moment when it truly calls for some riveting emotions. So, when you're just wandering the land, accomplishing small tasks, the music remains quiet, pensive, and ambient. When something big is going on... it's spine-chilling. Contrast is everything!

The sound effects are immersive because they draw from the environment, and you can often hear things coming before you see them. This is effective because when you are traveling around in real life, out in the woods or even on city streets, oftentimes you will hear things before you see them coming. This is something we have tended to take for granted, but you can tell this was intentionally designed in the game.

Of course, the art direction was gorgeous. I especially love the fact that the characters are not rendered in an attempt for photorealism like many triple A titles these days. You simply don't need that. Stylized, abstracted forms are more pleasing to the eye IMO. Attempting photorealistic characters in a video game is just too uncanny valley for my tastes.

The *colors*, man. The light and shadows. The composition. It's a visual masterpiece.

And the ending. I don't have to explain why it's so chilling and amazing.

What are you waiting for... buy this game!

reviewText:
After been hinted by it of Totalbiscuit, I decided to buy it last year. After seeing Totalbiscuit and [AReV]BavarianGod and having them already pointing out their arguments in their respected videos, I wondered if any review would be adding any additional insight. So after some thinking, I thought: lets discuss what the game did for me.

To me, the game was a joyous experience, with a twist. Due to the tone of the game being about hefty themes like love, companionship and fear. The hefty themes suggest that the game wants to have those themes be taken very seriously, and for me it did, though not in the extend it happened to the previous mentioned people.

One note should go to my favorite (and often overlooked) part of a game is sound: Though it forgoes the use of speech, Brothers does a damn fine job to fill up this gap by using gibberish talks, hand and feet communication and an awesome soundtrack (which you should buy btw) to provide the wholesale immersion.

This game felt like a game again, not someone who has set some knobs regarding which few game mechanics should be in a game, press 'create' and voila: a triple-a title.
No, this game seperates itself from that, in which it succeeds really well: its gameplay really let you immerse into the world, even though you're not seeing it from a first person view.

All in all, I think that this game is for people who dare step off their beloved franchise game, try a single game and find this one.

Ups:
+ Good Narritive
+ Heartfelt Story
+ Unique Game mechanics
+ SOUND!
+ MUSIC!

Downs:
- Short Story
- Difficulty

reviewText:
An incredibly powerful short story about 2 brothers on a quest through a dangerous and fantastic land to find a magic water with healing powers that can save their dying father.

The mechanics play just as big a part in the story as the story itself.
The design is nothing short of masterful. Every new puzzle is simple yet never easy and always rewarding to complete. Challenges are explained without the use of specific audio or textual direction; only pantomime and vocal tones without the use of a dechiperable language. I do think I knew the brothers' names by the end of the story, only because throughout the game each brother calls out to the other ever so often, each always repeating a specific word (similar to how you as a player come to grasp the name of the hero's horse in Shadow of the Colossus). Every dangerous situation with a new puzzle mechanic had always already been taught to the player in a safe sandbox area so that they are always prepared for when a situation called to re-use that mechanic in an unsafe part of the world. Never was anything similar to what you might call a modern tutorial" was ever needed.

One particular moment near the end of the game must be recognized. In this moment

reviewText:
If you're reading this, do yourself a favor and just buy Brothers - A tale of Two Sons right now.

Brothers, for lack of a better term, is a masterpiece IMHO. Somehow, Brothers delivers an emotional, compassionate story, without a single word of dialogue in the whole game. Charcaters do speak, but their language is Simmilar to Simlish (The Sims) I suppose. Although you cannot understand the language, You will still understand what is going on. You will have to prepare yourself for many emotions throughout the game. I will list a few I've experienced: Sadness, joy, wonder, curiousity, horror, excitement, and despair. Sounds a bit over the top? Well go see for yourself. You may experience emotions you never new existed.

Brothers perfectly marries Story with Game Mechanics. The best way i can explain it is that you play the story. Again, for lack of a better term, Brothers is a Singleplayer Co-op game. If you were not aware, You control two Brothers independently using the joysicks of your controller (Provided you use a controller). Contrary to the Notice above, The game will work with a keyboard, But I would not recommend it. Seperately controlling the two siblings, you traverse the game working together. I would not classify Brothers as a Puzzle Platformer, however. It's simply a journey. Which brings me to the final point.

Brothers took me roughly 3 hours to complete. I would say there is some replayability, but thats only because there are achievements you will miss and areas you may have skipped. So maybe 5 - 6 hours will be all you get out of Brothers, unless you play through games several times. I know that so few hours may not warrant the price for some people, but I promise you'll remember this game for as long as you live. I know I will.

reviewText:
If you're reading this, do yourself a favor and just buy Brothers - A tale of Two Sons right now.

Brothers, for lack of a better term, is a masterpiece IMHO. Somehow, Brothers delivers an emotional, compassionate story, without a single word of dialogue in the whole game. Charcaters do speak, but their language is Simmilar to Simlish (The Sims) I suppose. Although you cannot understand the language, You will still understand what is going on. You will have to prepare yourself for many emotions throughout the game. I will list a few I've experienced: Sadness, joy, wonder, curiousity, horror, excitement, and despair. Sounds a bit over the top? Well go see for yourself. You may experience emotions you never new existed.

Brothers perfectly marries Story with Game Mechanics. The best way i can explain it is that you play the story. Again, for lack of a better term, Brothers is a Singleplayer Co-op game. If you were not aware, You control two Brothers independently using the joysicks of your controller (Provided you use a controller). Contrary to the Notice above, The game will work with a keyboard, But I would not recommend it. Seperately controlling the two siblings, you traverse the game working together. I would not classify Brothers as a Puzzle Platformer, however. It's simply a journey. Which brings me to the final point.

Brothers took me roughly 3 hours to complete. I would say there is some replayability, but thats only because there are achievements you will miss and areas you may have skipped. So maybe 5 - 6 hours will be all you get out of Brothers, unless you play through games several times. I know that so few hours may not warrant the price for some people, but I promise you'll remember this game for as long as you live. I know I will.

reviewText: If you're looking for a quick game to play, get Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons. It works best with a controller, but can be played with a keyboard. The gist of it is that you control two brothers simultaneously to solve puzzles and complete action sequences. It gets awfully clever on you, and there are only very minimal cues in the game. That is, it rarely tells you what buttons you need to press. In fact, you've only got the movement controls for each brother and a button to make each of them separately interact with stuff in the environment. There's dialogue but it's audible only in gibberish and only serves to convey character emotion and build on the personalities of the cast. Through the journey you come to know the characters by the quirky way you control them, i.e. you'll probably end up paying more attention to one brother, while the other larks off in some other direction (keeping track of two characters at once is deceptively difficult.)\n\nIt's only a few hours long, but the price is right. It's almost criminal that during the last steam sale I was able to get it for something like $2.50. Normal price $15, it's actually on sale for $7.50 right now. Get it.

reviewText:
Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is basically Ico, except you control both Ico and Yorda at the same time. It features similarly well-designed puzzles that utilize an impressively intuitive control scheme as you run through a world that manages to tell a completely wordless story.

I havenâ€™t tried to play this game with a keyboard but I probably wouldnâ€™t recommended it. On a 360 pad you control each brother with one analog stick, and each trigger serves as an â€œinteractâ€ button for each of them. Through this, Brothers puts you through what is every bit the classic adventure game in the Ico, Another World, and Prince of Persia tradition.

Each brother has different abilities -- the older brother is stronger and can swim but the younger brother can fit in smaller places. Through this, Brothers manages to give you puzzles that are surprisingly ingenious despite not being very complex. None of the puzzles took me more than a few seconds to work out, but at the same time none of them felt stupid. Iâ€™m still not sure how Starbreeze struck that balance. You can see a similar balance in the storyline.

The gameâ€™s Sims-style gibberish manages to communicate that two brothers -- one in the midst of adolescence and the other reaching the end of childhood, must go on a quest to find a legendary medicine for their ailing father. Thereâ€™s a lot of other interesting and well-told stuff in there as the brothers meet ever-wilder characters on their journey.

Similar to Team Icoâ€™s games, Brothers also takes you through environments that immediately feel like they have stories of their own, like the aftermath of a battlefield or the wake of a natural disaster. Furthermore, the game doesnâ€™t even tell you the full story of whatâ€™s transpired in front of you, it just letâ€™s you infer things.

The art direction in Brothers serves all these environments and characters well despite it being quite modest in the technical area -- no fancy effects or anything and the system requirements donâ€™t list any recommended settings, only minimum. Everything is in a sort of round, chunky aesthetic which seems to play to the Unreal 3 Engineâ€™s strengths similarly to Gears of War 3.

Brothers is a very tightly-put-together little adventure game that hits the hallmarks of what itâ€™s probably trying to evoke: inspired fairy-tale locales, smart-but-intuitive gameplay, and an emotional storyline that doesnâ€™t rely too much on cut scenes or any text, though the whole game will last you no more than three hours.

reviewText:
The good:
*  The gameplay is innovative.  Controlling both characters is neat.
*  The puzzles are fun, if a bit simple.
*  The world is fantastic and exciting.  Beautiful art and interesting setting.
*  For the most part I was on the edge of my seat waiting to see what would happen on the next part of their adventure.

The bad:
*  The main storyline is aweful.  Extremely cliche, and where the designer expects the player to feel emotional impact there is none, because he never bothered to develop the characters in a meaningful way.  The last 15 minutes of the game were painful to paly through because of how forced it felt.  Luckily through most of the game the main story stays out of the way.
*  The controls are cludgy when they work, and I had to edit a .ini file burried in the games configs in order for it to use my controller correctly (the left sticks Y was flipped, and the game's built in menus don't have ways to change things like that)
*  The game is very slow to start (and slow to end)  The first 15 minutes of the game feel like pointlessly running around a town.
*  The game is very short.  All of it high quality but it wont last you very long.

Despite my gripes I found the game to be a lot of fun to play, and well worth the price of admission if you can pick it up on sale.  Just don't expect a deep story, and be willing to deal with some wonky controls.

8/10

This is a coming of age tale where two brothers embark on an epic journey to retrieve medicine to save their dying father.

reviewText:
This game had a lot to live up to - if it's near perfect reviews weren't enough, the fact that it'd touch on such a personal and subjective experience as brotherhood left me doubting that it could live up to it's name.

The core of the game revolves around two brothers, that set out in search for an elixer that will save their father from a deadly illness. While this seems like a rather weak call to action, the world really is so beautiful that you won't care. A playthrough lasts about three hours, and the story really flourishes in the second half of the game, once you've had time to get your head around the mechanics.

The brothers are unique and lovingly crafted, each with his own personality and flaws. And the world itself cuts no corners; reminiscient of the beautiful (and sometimes dark) lands of fairy tales that we grew up with.

If you're on the fence, don't be. It's one of the best three hour experiences that you can have for under five dollars. Buy this now and play it through like a movie. You definitely won't regret it.

reviewText:
Plot/setting: This game places you in the shoes of two brothers who take it upon themselves to find a cure for their father. This adventure will take them across a vast land filled with various kinds of fantasy characters and settings. The story and setting are absolutely the main attractions of this game. The plot  starts off as the run of the mill story, but once the game gets going you will run into some interesting situations that makes this game what it is. One gripe I had early on is that all of the characters speak in some sort of gibberish, and while the animations of the characters convey their feelings adequately it can feel like you are missing out. That said the lack of actual dialogue grew on me and I actually prefer it.

Gameplay/constrols: This game is unique as you control both brothers using a stick and bumper button for each brother. This is the reason a controller is highly recommended for playing. I did not try using KB and mouse so I cannot compare, but I imagine it is difficult. For the most part the control scheme works with only the occasional mixup in my coordination of controlling the brothers. The game is filled with puzzles that consist of one borther using one strength to do one task like fitting through small areas and the other brother pulling big heavy levers. There are also some puzzles and platforming aspects that require both brothers to work together. Overall the puzzles will not be challenging at all, but they are entertaining nonetheless.

Length/replayability: This game is very short and only clocks in at around 3 hours. There are no sidequests, only little interactions with the world you can have; most of which are acheivements. Once you have completed the game and got all of te acheivements though there will be no reason to replay this game for a long time.

Overall: The price of $15 for this game is steep considering it's length, but despite that I absolutely recommened this game especially if it is on sale.

reviewText:
My thoughts on Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons:

What an amazingly beautiful game! I picked this up quite a while a go during a sale and only because I heard YouTube personality TotalBisquit say this was his favourite game.
After playing (and finishing) it, I can understand why.

You follow the two Brothers on their quest to find a rare medicine to cure their father and help them climb mountains, fly across valleys, make their way through villages and castles, across devastaded battlefields and frozen rivers. The level design is just awesome and so beautiful I couldn't help but wish to be living there. The soundtrack too is great and fits the game and the mood perfectly.
While it takes some time to really get used to the controls (Xbox controller is required) - you control both brothers at once, using both sticks - it never gets frustrating or annoying as the game helps you out a lot and never really is too hard to be blamed on the controls.
There are no fights or puzzles, just some smal objectives like having to pull a lever with one brother while hangling across a pit with the other, in order to create a path for the big brother once you reached the other side. May sound boring, but the landscapes and the characters somehow get you entertained anyway. Plus, the game is easily beatable in under two hours, so there isn't much time to get bored anyway.
Biggest highlight of the game however is how it makes you like the characters in a way only few other games do, and the ending deserves a special mention too as it is just beautiful and really really really well made. Did I already mention how beautiful the landscapes are?

Highly recommended for anyone, especially during a sale!

reviewText:
An incredibly powerful short story about 2 brothers on a quest through a dangerous and fantastic land to find a magic water with healing powers that can save their dying father.

The mechanics play just as big a part in the story as the story itself.
The design is nothing short of masterful. Every new puzzle is simple yet never easy and always rewarding to complete. Challenges are explained without the use of specific audio or textual direction; only pantomime and vocal tones without the use of a dechiperable language. I do think I knew the brothers' names by the end of the story, only because throughout the game each brother calls out to the other ever so often, each always repeating a specific word (similar to how you as a player come to grasp the name of the hero's horse in Shadow of the Colossus). Every dangerous situation with a new puzzle mechanic had always already been taught to the player in a safe sandbox area so that they are always prepared for when a situation called to re-use that mechanic in an unsafe part of the world. Never was anything similar to what you might call a modern tutorial" was ever needed.

One particular moment near the end of the game must be recognized. In this moment
date: the designers pull off one of the most amazing feats of creative direction I've ever seen. There is a very specific set of challenges with an ostensibly new mechanic that is not explicitly explained in the ways most of the previous ones have been... but the designers know from your experiences in the game
recommended: you will naturally try to solve it in a very specific way. To "count on" a player to not only figure something like this out but to also grasp WHY they made this decision usually is a bad idea or requires a tutorial or some sort of cookie to let you know why some choice was made

reviewText:
If you're reading this, do yourself a favor and just buy Brothers - A tale of Two Sons right now.

Brothers, for lack of a better term, is a masterpiece IMHO. Somehow, Brothers delivers an emotional, compassionate story, without a single word of dialogue in the whole game. Charcaters do speak, but their language is Simmilar to Simlish (The Sims) I suppose. Although you cannot understand the language, You will still understand what is going on. You will have to prepare yourself for many emotions throughout the game. I will list a few I've experienced: Sadness, joy, wonder, curiousity, horror, excitement, and despair. Sounds a bit over the top? Well go see for yourself. You may experience emotions you never new existed.

Brothers perfectly marries Story with Game Mechanics. The best way i can explain it is that you play the story. Again, for lack of a better term, Brothers is a Singleplayer Co-op game. If you were not aware, You control two Brothers independently using the joysicks of your controller (Provided you use a controller). Contrary to the Notice above, The game will work with a keyboard, But I would not recommend it. Seperately controlling the two siblings, you traverse the game working together. I would not classify Brothers as a Puzzle Platformer, however. It's simply a journey. Which brings me to the final point.

Brothers took me roughly 3 hours to complete. I would say there is some replayability, but thats only because there are achievements you will miss and areas you may have skipped. So maybe 5 - 6 hours will be all you get out of Brothers, unless you play through games several times. I know that so few hours may not warrant the price for some people, but I promise you'll remember this game for as long as you live. I know I will.

reviewText:
Though people are no longer with us, that does not mean that they are gone forever. We do not need to have the person next to us to have them influence us. And this game portrays that idea perfectly. It is a simple story of two brothers and their journey together to help find a cure for their father. You control one brother with the left thumbstick and the other brother with the right thumbstick. And throughout the journey, they have to rely on each other to get past certain obstacles. The story is very moving and portrays life and death in an interesting way through its cutscenes.

The game is not all doom and gloom though. There are many beautiful moments that depict the beauty of life, whether you're stopping a man from committing suicide or reuniting a mother turtle with its children. Although those are optional tasks, it is left to the player to make those decisions and make this tough journey bearable.

The game can get a little glitchy from time to time but it left such an impact on me that the negatives did not bother me so much. It is a fairly short game but this is definitely something that is going to stick with you.

reviewText:
First off; You definitely need a controller with 2 analog sticks.
The game can be mapped to keyboard but you are robbing yourself of the full experience as the
developer intended.

That said;

The game is short and depends on the main mechanic of controlling 2 characters at the same time.
One with each analog stick and each brother also has one action button.
It's simple. The puzzles aren't that complicated at all, but they are amazingly clever on how they play up the simple nature of the controls. It's mechanics also purposefully serve as a narritive device through the puzzle solving and both characters rely on one another to progress on their journey.

This game also does a superb job of telling a story through the gameplay. No dialogue whatsoever.
Yet it is a powerful and amazing adventure with epic scenes and harrowing moments.

It's great. About as long as a movie, and costs about the same.
Definitely worth your time.

reviewText:
The game lacked a lot of impact for me and the story wasn't anything to write home about. However it was still a nice experience and the art style and graphics are quite nice.

(I played this game entirely on the xbox 360 gamepad by the way.)

This game felt like a dark childrens book, it was quite whimsical at times, very funny and silly, but it got hauntingly dark too. And thankfully, without remorse. That, is a very strong mark for this game. I think this may be a spoiler, but I was really expecting it to undo what it had done. I am very glad that it didn't.

Before I get to where I want to go, I want to talk about the controls. The controls tangled your fingers up into a knot, I don't really mind that. But with the very simple control layout, this game controlled very basically. The controls were not interesting in the slightest and really it just boiled down to building a control scheme onto that same controller in essence. Wasn't really anything ground breaking. You could change your camera view, move two characters with the analouge sticks. And then you have two action triggers/keys, for each of the respective characters. So really you'd just move around and press the action trigger/key and see what happens.

By the way, this game's store page lied, you DON'T need a xbox 360 controller to play this game. You can play it on the keyboard too as I could tell in the options menu.


Anyway, I don't really know how to explain why it felt like and experience to me over a story. Perhaps it has to do with how shallow everything felt regarding characters. I felt like absolutely no one had a real backstory or depth besides the young boy. Using them to interact with the world had very expressive reactions. The older brother was boring, he was completely neutral the entire story and just struck me as a faceless robot kind of chugging along on this quest. Even his 1 flashback was really shallow and boring and felt irrelevant. It just reminded me of the father i'm trying to save. It didn't give the brother any face-value and only seemed to show aggression to his brother at time when his brother was unokay with something. That or he'd just show leadership or be protective of his brother. Other than that, he had absolutely no depth whatsoever and he was easily forgettable. Really, I felt only interested in him cause he looked cool. I didn't like the little brother because he looks like a doof to me. But after watching the little bothers events and personality and backstory unfold a little bit (not enough I'd say) he was much more interesting and likeable.

Next up is the graphics. Graphics were good, I mean. I am unsure about the detailing, at times they felt not shaded enough, detailed enough, or they didn't flow together well enough. Though the graphics and displays and scenery was good enough to definitely warrant a second playthrough with your finger on the steam screencapture key, that's for sure. Definitely good desktop wallpaper material in here. Also can be aspring for some artists I can imagine.


There were some moments of tenseness in this game, surprisingly. As the game got progressively dark and took a really unexpected dip into limbo-like depressive stuff all of a sudden. I think there was only one or two parts that really made me have to actually pay attention to my controls, very sure it was once only. And that was a damn good part, glad it wasn't necessary to the story, felt very important to me though. And I like that, i'm glad I got a opportunity to side-track in the game and find things that were important to me instead of the characters. It was nice.

That being said, this games trip into darkness and doing scenarios that aren't often done in video games was truly surprising and i'm really glad they didn't regret any of the decisions they decided to do in it. Because I feel like that's what saved the game for me a little bit. It was a nice journey and it was fun and relaxing.
Most deaths in this game really only occur when the controls are a little too unclear, but you figure out what went wrong almost immediately, so it's not big deal.

That being said, I'd really like to give the developers a BIG thumbs up to one part they made me do. It was something I never want to do in a video game ever again, it just felt all kinds of wrong and messed up to me. I'd like to compliment another part about it, but. I won't, cause spoilers. But, it was good. And i'm glad you didn't reverse it.


Also, lastly. The music. ...It was really easy to ignore it. It really was. It wasn't bad by any means, but it wasn't anything to remember. When my mind actually did pick up some of the tracks, I was instantly dissuaded to bother youtube searching it because that same track felt like a reoccuring theme in any deep" moments. Whenever something interested happened or a cutscene happened
date: tracks that sound like that song I heard. Sounded just like remixed versions of it with added or removed instruments and spacing between instrument play times and so on so forth to fit the timing they wanted to match or feelings they wanted to convey in the cut scenes. So the only interesting track was pretty much just rehashed to me in a uninteresting way and most of the scenes were impactful. Even the ones that were supposed to bother you.\nAlso with that

reviewText:
I recommend that you subject yourself to this game, because its like come along once in a very long time, and usually on consoles.

Visually stunning and with a soundtrack that is perfectly pitched to compliment those visuals, Brothers is an amazing game from a purely technical perspective. That doesn't really matter however.

Brothers is an amazing tale, conveyed almost without words in a way reminiscent of Ico and Shadow of the Colossus. The charazterization of the characters is also in itself simple, but strong. You will love these brothers and sympathize with their struggle just as you'll stand amazed at the detail and imagination invested into this fictional world, and that's part of the tragedy. The game KNOWS what you think it is. It knows what you expect. It's masterfully directed and built to get you emotionally invested in its story.

Saying any more than that would spoil the surprises you'll have along the way, but fair warning: the game is not a happy-go-lucky fairy tale and it will shock you, scare you and ultimately make you cry your soul out.

10/10.

reviewText:
Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is exactly what a short indie game should be.  The game is short (approximately 2-3 hours) but what it does in that time is more than some games try to do in 30 hours.  The puzzles and the controlling brothers mechanic are used exretemely well and there really isn't a great deal of repetitiveness in those puzzles.  Each puzzle is a short unique puzzle to solve and then move quickly to the next puzzle/story element.

There is not a lot of fluff or down time in the game.  It is paced exteremly well, moving from puzzle to story to puzzle to story.  It's not that the game can be beat in one sitting, it's that the game is so well paced that you want to finish it in one sitting.  There's no big down boring parts or excessively frustrating puzzles, just small simple well excuted game play that makes you want to keep moving on.

The world that the developers created to tell their story in was beautiful.  There was some really unique areas with some unique characters as well.

Everything comes together in one great package to make one of the best indie games that I have played.  Highly recommend the game to anyone looking for a great indie experience.

reviewText:
The good:
*  The gameplay is innovative.  Controlling both characters is neat.
*  The puzzles are fun, if a bit simple.
*  The world is fantastic and exciting.  Beautiful art and interesting setting.
*  For the most part I was on the edge of my seat waiting to see what would happen on the next part of their adventure.

The bad:
*  The main storyline is aweful.  Extremely cliche, and where the designer expects the player to feel emotional impact there is none, because he never bothered to develop the characters in a meaningful way.  The last 15 minutes of the game were painful to paly through because of how forced it felt.  Luckily through most of the game the main story stays out of the way.
*  The controls are cludgy when they work, and I had to edit a .ini file burried in the games configs in order for it to use my controller correctly (the left sticks Y was flipped, and the game's built in menus don't have ways to change things like that)
*  The game is very slow to start (and slow to end)  The first 15 minutes of the game feel like pointlessly running around a town.
*  The game is very short.  All of it high quality but it wont last you very long.

Despite my gripes I found the game to be a lot of fun to play, and well worth the price of admission if you can pick it up on sale.  Just don't expect a deep story, and be willing to deal with some wonky controls.

8/10

reviewText:
This is a coming of age tale where two brothers embark on an epic journey to retrieve medicine to save their dying father.

The game play is unique because you control both brothers at the same time.  For this reason, the game requires a gamepad an cannot be played with a mouse and keyboard.  Each brother is controlled by an alalog stick and each brother has an action movement that is controlled by a trigger.   It takes a little getting used to controlling two characters with one controller, but since the game play is pretty simple, it's not too difficult to pick up.

The visuals in this game are beautiful and the story is captivating.  And most importantly, the game is fun.

Overall, this was a great game and I highly recommend it.  My only complaint is that it's pretty short.  I beat it in about 3 hours.

reviewText:
This game had a lot to live up to - if it's near perfect reviews weren't enough, the fact that it'd touch on such a personal and subjective experience as brotherhood left me doubting that it could live up to it's name.

The core of the game revolves around two brothers, that set out in search for an elixer that will save their father from a deadly illness. While this seems like a rather weak call to action, the world really is so beautiful that you won't care. A playthrough lasts about three hours, and the story really flourishes in the second half of the game, once you've had time to get your head around the mechanics.

The brothers are unique and lovingly crafted, each with his own personality and flaws. And the world itself cuts no corners; reminiscient of the beautiful (and sometimes dark) lands of fairy tales that we grew up with.

If you're on the fence, don't be. It's one of the best three hour experiences that you can have for under five dollars. Buy this now and play it through like a movie. You definitely won't regret it.

reviewText:
Calm, melancholy, sad and oh so beautiful.

The music, the graphic and the atmosphere are hauntingly beautiful. I can only recommend everyone who is looking for a new way of experiencing a fairytale to try this game. Well, I recommend this game actually to everyone. The loving craftsmanship the game makers put into this game is present every second.

I am playing this game the second time now, again together with my daughter. So what are you waiting for?

reviewText:
Before i start the review, I'll explain a little bit about my experience playing this game:

I first played the first few minutes of this game at a friend's house. He got me interested in the game and a few days later i bought it when it was on sale. Because this game is about 2 brothers, i took the oppertunity to play this game with my little brother (10 years younger than me). We ended up finishing the entire game together, playing at the same time or occasionally taking turns when one of us was about to die of sleep deprivation. This game is meant to be single player, but you can technically make it a co-op if you share the controller. So grab your brother (or better yet, 2 misbehaving siblings you want to teach a lesson about taking turns and co-operating with one another) and start the game up!

Regarding myself and the little brother i played it with, we're 10 years apart. I'm nearing my 20's and he's still in elementary school at the time of this review. I wouldn't reccomend playing this game with a younger brother whose uncomfortable with themes of death and darkness. If you decide to play with a younger brother who doesn't understand the concept of death yet or is slowly learning the concept of death, this game may be a good way to introduce them to those themes, but this game CAN GET DARK. The game has many themes of death and it's very much a coming of age story for both brothers. In the game you'll encounter dead bodies, scary graveyards, nature coming to life trying to kill you,  SPIDERS , and an NPC 'tempting his own fate' to put it lightly... So just use your own judgement regarding your experience with your little brother of choice. As for the adorable child i played with, he can tolerate most things and only flat out refused to play the game in one section because he witnessed some gore he wasn't expecting but easily shook that off and played with me again immediately after that section was over. We played the game up until the end, wtinessed the ending together and he is not psychologically scarred by it in any way. We only used a walkthrough ONE time and even after the game was over we jokingly call eachother what the Brothers call eachother in the game.

Ok, now onto the review:

Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is a puzzle/adventure game similar to the likes of ICO and Shadow of the Collasus for the PS2. The world Brothers takes place in is GORGEOUS to look at and feels incredibly massive but dangerous at the same time.  If you love RPGs and puzzles with huge worlds you'll love the way this one looks and feels. Unlike ICO and Shadow, the controls for brothers are extremely simple. You move with the analog sticks and interact with R2/L2. You can play solo controlling both titular brothers or grab any male sibling you get along with and each of you can share the controller, controlling 1 brother each. Both brothers are also very balanced. Big Brother (Maya?) is strong and tall but he doesn't jump very high or run as fast as Little Brother (Maii?), who is weaker and shorter but can jump higher. They can help eachother around the enviornment by picking eachother up, helping eachother up ladders, solve puzzles together in ways renimicent to ICO and Yorda and they're enjoyable to play as despite speaking a nonsense language (also very similar to the language spoken in ICO).

The story is a simple fetch quest. The boys father gets sick and they must retrieve an antidote from a tree hidden up in the mountains. And that's it. The story doesn't get more complex than that save for the fact their mother has died by drowning and Little Brother is also trauamtized by that event and unlike Big Brother, he can't swim. The game isn't so much about a story, it's more about a journey. The landscapes are beautiful and while wandering the world i couldn't help but want to know more about the lore of the world they're travelling through. It feels very Scandinavian in nature, what with all the giants, the beautiful snowscape, the water and the beautiful castles. I can't get over how wonderfult he game looks. At first glance, this looks like one of those games that'll look better than it actually is but in the case of Brothers, i say the looks are just a bonus for the journey. As for the journey is self, all the puzzles are solveable. If you play with a friend or a brother of your own, niether of you will get too frustrated.

One thing that prevents me from buying most adventure/puzzle games is if the puzzles will be solveable. It's what makes or breaks a puzzle game. And thankfully despite the occasional camera wonky-ness all of the puzzles are solveable without a walkthrough. For myself and my brother, we only used a walkthrough for one puzzle we were confused on and after 10 minutes of testing theories we gave up and resorted to youtube. But other than that small experience, you could easily get through all the puzzles and they can all be solved without ripping your hair out trying to retrace your steps. Everything you need is always in the right place, where you need to go is always hinted at, you sometimes just need to look from a new perspective or look a little more carefully. For me at least, i enjoyed that the puzzles weren't too complex. If the puzzles are too complex that's usually the point where i give up on the game. And the puzzle layout is especially useful if you plan on playing with your younger brother.

This is one of those rare occasions where i can say nothing bad about this game. Maybe 1 thing i can complain about the is the normal price which is 14.99, but i bought this game on sale and ended up getting is for around 3.75 (something like that) and completed the whole game in about 5/6 hours spanning a few different days because i was playing this with another person. Had i played the game solo, i likely would've finished it a lot faster. I'm one of those gamers who wants alot of gameplay for their money. Because i got this on sale i'd say i'm pretty lucky but the normal price may be a bit high if you value how many hours you'll get out of a game, but thankfully this game ain't 60 bucks, so 15 isn't that much of a bad price in my opinion.

Yeah, i have ABSOLUTELY NOTHING BAD TO SAY. It's very surprising 0_0;

This is just one of those games where you love the journey and can't see much bad about it.
It was an especially good bonding experience playing this game with my own brother, as we discussed how different puzzles could be solved, helped eachother progress through the journey and occasionally have mom yell at us when we were yelling at the brothers on screen. I can't imagine playing this game alone save maybe for the occasion where you've already beaten the game and wanna play it for nostalgia, gawk at the beauty of the setting or just wanna get all the achievements. I wholly suggest playing this game with another person (especially a brother).

I give Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons 10 sets of brothers out of 5!
