reviewText:
The game lacked a lot of impact for me and the story wasn't anything to write home about. However it was still a nice experience and the art style and graphics are quite nice.

(I played this game entirely on the xbox 360 gamepad by the way.)

This game felt like a dark childrens book, it was quite whimsical at times, very funny and silly, but it got hauntingly dark too. And thankfully, without remorse. That, is a very strong mark for this game. I think this may be a spoiler, but I was really expecting it to undo what it had done. I am very glad that it didn't.

Before I get to where I want to go, I want to talk about the controls. The controls tangled your fingers up into a knot, I don't really mind that. But with the very simple control layout, this game controlled very basically. The controls were not interesting in the slightest and really it just boiled down to building a control scheme onto that same controller in essence. Wasn't really anything ground breaking. You could change your camera view, move two characters with the analouge sticks. And then you have two action triggers/keys, for each of the respective characters. So really you'd just move around and press the action trigger/key and see what happens.

By the way, this game's store page lied, you DON'T need a xbox 360 controller to play this game. You can play it on the keyboard too as I could tell in the options menu.


Anyway, I don't really know how to explain why it felt like and experience to me over a story. Perhaps it has to do with how shallow everything felt regarding characters. I felt like absolutely no one had a real backstory or depth besides the young boy. Using them to interact with the world had very expressive reactions. The older brother was boring, he was completely neutral the entire story and just struck me as a faceless robot kind of chugging along on this quest. Even his 1 flashback was really shallow and boring and felt irrelevant. It just reminded me of the father i'm trying to save. It didn't give the brother any face-value and only seemed to show aggression to his brother at time when his brother was unokay with something. That or he'd just show leadership or be protective of his brother. Other than that, he had absolutely no depth whatsoever and he was easily forgettable. Really, I felt only interested in him cause he looked cool. I didn't like the little brother because he looks like a doof to me. But after watching the little bothers events and personality and backstory unfold a little bit (not enough I'd say) he was much more interesting and likeable.

Next up is the graphics. Graphics were good, I mean. I am unsure about the detailing, at times they felt not shaded enough, detailed enough, or they didn't flow together well enough. Though the graphics and displays and scenery was good enough to definitely warrant a second playthrough with your finger on the steam screencapture key, that's for sure. Definitely good desktop wallpaper material in here. Also can be aspring for some artists I can imagine.


There were some moments of tenseness in this game, surprisingly. As the game got progressively dark and took a really unexpected dip into limbo-like depressive stuff all of a sudden. I think there was only one or two parts that really made me have to actually pay attention to my controls, very sure it was once only. And that was a damn good part, glad it wasn't necessary to the story, felt very important to me though. And I like that, i'm glad I got a opportunity to side-track in the game and find things that were important to me instead of the characters. It was nice.

That being said, this games trip into darkness and doing scenarios that aren't often done in video games was truly surprising and i'm really glad they didn't regret any of the decisions they decided to do in it. Because I feel like that's what saved the game for me a little bit. It was a nice journey and it was fun and relaxing.
Most deaths in this game really only occur when the controls are a little too unclear, but you figure out what went wrong almost immediately, so it's not big deal.

That being said, I'd really like to give the developers a BIG thumbs up to one part they made me do. It was something I never want to do in a video game ever again, it just felt all kinds of wrong and messed up to me. I'd like to compliment another part about it, but. I won't, cause spoilers. But, it was good. And i'm glad you didn't reverse it.


Also, lastly. The music. ...It was really easy to ignore it. It really was. It wasn't bad by any means, but it wasn't anything to remember. When my mind actually did pick up some of the tracks, I was instantly dissuaded to bother youtube searching it because that same track felt like a reoccuring theme in any deep" moments. Whenever something interested happened or a cutscene happened
date: tracks that sound like that song I heard. Sounded just like remixed versions of it with added or removed instruments and spacing between instrument play times and so on so forth to fit the timing they wanted to match or feelings they wanted to convey in the cut scenes. So the only interesting track was pretty much just rehashed to me in a uninteresting way and most of the scenes were impactful. Even the ones that were supposed to bother you.\nAlso with that
recommended: I don't get why they put this skyrim-sounding song at the end of the game. It really made no sense

reviewText:
A game, so masterfully crafted, it's breathtaking;
Brothers: A tale of two sons puts you in the shoes of two young brothers (hence the name of the game), trying to help their father by finding a cure.
You venture out into the mysterious and strange lands, populated by creatures you'd not expect to exist.
Brothers is a game made solely for the purpose of telling a good, interesting story, which would be more than good enough to sell as a book.

The artwork and music are both ingenius and although the visuals may be outdated, they immerse you anyways.

At this point I'd like to point out the following things:
This game is ONLY playable via a compatible controller!
The visuals are not top notch, please view ingame-screenshots or watch a short video to see, if you're okay with that!
The story is VERY short. If you calculate achievement hunting into the mix, you'll barely scratch the 3 hour mark!
If you can look past all that, I'd say, that you should go pick it up. Otherwise I'd advise to wait for the game to be in sale!

I hope you found my review helpful and that it aided you deciding, wether or not to buy this product!

reviewText:
One of the most adorable and touching experiences I've had in gaming.

You control both brothers with a gamepad simultaneously and drive them through a journey to help their father. The characters speak gibberish, there is no dialogue or subtitles, but that doesn't put you off from the experience, to the contrary; it takes the focus beam and points it at emotions and surroundings more than objectives and achievements. You will appreciate the little things in this game that become huge, such as the environment that looks like it came out of a painting and how each brother has a different way of dealing with things. I caught myself stalling to look around for secrets or ways to mess with the locals more than I dare to admit. *clears throat*

10/10; Flawless, wonderful experience. It's ~ 3hrs of gameplay (or more if you go for the achievements), so you may want to get it on sale. Highly recommended anyways.


p.s. keep yourself hydrated ;_;

reviewText:
Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is exactly what a short indie game should be.  The game is short (approximately 2-3 hours) but what it does in that time is more than some games try to do in 30 hours.  The puzzles and the controlling brothers mechanic are used exretemely well and there really isn't a great deal of repetitiveness in those puzzles.  Each puzzle is a short unique puzzle to solve and then move quickly to the next puzzle/story element.

There is not a lot of fluff or down time in the game.  It is paced exteremly well, moving from puzzle to story to puzzle to story.  It's not that the game can be beat in one sitting, it's that the game is so well paced that you want to finish it in one sitting.  There's no big down boring parts or excessively frustrating puzzles, just small simple well excuted game play that makes you want to keep moving on.

The world that the developers created to tell their story in was beautiful.  There was some really unique areas with some unique characters as well.

Everything comes together in one great package to make one of the best indie games that I have played.  Highly recommend the game to anyone looking for a great indie experience.

reviewText: From my childhood I maintained a sensible and close relation with fairy tales. Later on that turned into an affection for cartoons, providing an enchanting athmosphere for the never-to-grow-up child inside of us. If you have ever longed for grasping that feel of the ancient lovable fairytales in a game, this title is ment for you.\nBrothers places together all the parts necessary to build up a story around you that will stick you down into your chair. You start with a sick father and two worried brothers, setting out for the journey to get the cure which can save the old man. The game is basically made for co-op play on one machine, but it can be a tricky  finger excercise for single player as well. We have played through the whole adventure with my girlfriend in two days. That might seem a bit short, but considering the common adventure, it turned out to be just the right amount of time to delight the both of us. The game mechanincs are quite simple: one brother suitable for the first move of the puzzle goes ahead while the other will depend on the former's help to push through. One striking feature is the storytelling without a single articulate word. The characters behave and talk in a way that will surely make you understand whatever is happening at the moment. Among such circumstances imagery will take the leading role and that is another remarkable aspect of the game. Every last frame of it is well-planned and all of the screenshots you take would make a nice picture in your bedroom (believe me, or look it up in my screenshot section - spoilers at later pictures!!). The textures, tones and camera settings build up a marvelously charming athmosphere, leaving you stunned for several seconds with the scenery. You can practically feel the hours of carefuly artistic work put into the job all throughout your adventure. Not only is the artistically composed masterpiece a memorable experience, but it also hints you slightly with fable like qualities. I would hate to say too much, I suggest you jump right into it.

The world Brothers takes place in is GORGEOUS to look at and feels incredibly massive but dangerous at the same time.  If you love RPGs and puzzles with huge worlds you'll love the way this one looks and feels. Unlike ICO and Shadow, the controls for brothers are extremely simple. You move with the analog sticks and interact with R2/L2. You can play solo controlling both titular brothers or grab any male sibling you get along with and each of you can share the controller, controlling 1 brother each. Both brothers are also very balanced. Big Brother (Maya?) is strong and tall but he doesn't jump very high or run as fast as Little Brother (Maii?), who is weaker and shorter but can jump higher. They can help eachother around the enviornment by picking eachother up, helping eachother up ladders, solve puzzles together in ways renimicent to ICO and Yorda and they're enjoyable to play as despite speaking a nonsense language (also very similar to the language spoken in ICO).

The story is a simple fetch quest. The boys father gets sick and they must retrieve an antidote from a tree hidden up in the mountains. And that's it. The story doesn't get more complex than that save for the fact their mother has died by drowning and Little Brother is also trauamtized by that event and unlike Big Brother, he can't swim. The game isn't so much about a story, it's more about a journey. The landscapes are beautiful and while wandering the world i couldn't help but want to know more about the lore of the world they're travelling through. It feels very Scandinavian in nature, what with all the giants, the beautiful snowscape, the water and the beautiful castles. I can't get over how wonderfult he game looks. At first glance, this looks like one of those games that'll look better than it actually is but in the case of Brothers, i say the looks are just a bonus for the journey. As for the journey is self, all the puzzles are solveable. If you play with a friend or a brother of your own, niether of you will get too frustrated.

One thing that prevents me from buying most adventure/puzzle games is if the puzzles will be solveable. It's what makes or breaks a puzzle game. And thankfully despite the occasional camera wonky-ness all of the puzzles are solveable without a walkthrough. For myself and my brother, we only used a walkthrough for one puzzle we were confused on and after 10 minutes of testing theories we gave up and resorted to youtube. But other than that small experience, you could easily get through all the puzzles and they can all be solved without ripping your hair out trying to retrace your steps. Everything you need is always in the right place, where you need to go is always hinted at, you sometimes just need to look from a new perspective or look a little more carefully. For me at least, i enjoyed that the puzzles weren't too complex. If the puzzles are too complex that's usually the point where i give up on the game. And the puzzle layout is especially useful if you plan on playing with your younger brother.

This is one of those rare occasions where i can say nothing bad about this game. Maybe 1 thing i can complain about the is the normal price which is 14.99, but i bought this game on sale and ended up getting is for around 3.75 (something like that) and completed the whole game in about 5/6 hours spanning a few different days because i was playing this with another person. Had i played the game solo, i likely would've finished it a lot faster. I'm one of those gamers who wants alot of gameplay for their money. Because i got this on sale i'd say i'm pretty lucky but the normal price may be a bit high if you value how many hours you'll get out of a game, but thankfully this game ain't 60 bucks, so 15 isn't that much of a bad price in my opinion.

Yeah, i have ABSOLUTELY NOTHING BAD TO SAY. It's very surprising 0_0;

This is just one of those games where you love the journey and can't see much bad about it.
It was an especially good bonding experience playing this game with my own brother, as we discussed how different puzzles could be solved, helped eachother progress through the journey and occasionally have mom yell at us when we were yelling at the brothers on screen. I can't imagine playing this game alone save maybe for the occasion where you've already beaten the game and wanna play it for nostalgia, gawk at the beauty of the setting or just wanna get all the achievements. I wholly suggest playing this game with another person (especially a brother).

I give Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons 10 sets of brothers out of 5!

reviewText:
The game lacked a lot of impact for me and the story wasn't anything to write home about. However it was still a nice experience and the art style and graphics are quite nice.

(I played this game entirely on the xbox 360 gamepad by the way.)

This game felt like a dark childrens book, it was quite whimsical at times, very funny and silly, but it got hauntingly dark too. And thankfully, without remorse. That, is a very strong mark for this game. I think this may be a spoiler, but I was really expecting it to undo what it had done. I am very glad that it didn't.

Before I get to where I want to go, I want to talk about the controls. The controls tangled your fingers up into a knot, I don't really mind that. But with the very simple control layout, this game controlled very basically. The controls were not interesting in the slightest and really it just boiled down to building a control scheme onto that same controller in essence. Wasn't really anything ground breaking. You could change your camera view, move two characters with the analouge sticks. And then you have two action triggers/keys, for each of the respective characters. So really you'd just move around and press the action trigger/key and see what happens.

By the way, this game's store page lied, you DON'T need a xbox 360 controller to play this game. You can play it on the keyboard too as I could tell in the options menu.


Anyway, I don't really know how to explain why it felt like and experience to me over a story. Perhaps it has to do with how shallow everything felt regarding characters. I felt like absolutely no one had a real backstory or depth besides the young boy. Using them to interact with the world had very expressive reactions. The older brother was boring, he was completely neutral the entire story and just struck me as a faceless robot kind of chugging along on this quest. Even his 1 flashback was really shallow and boring and felt irrelevant. It just reminded me of the father i'm trying to save. It didn't give the brother any face-value and only seemed to show aggression to his brother at time when his brother was unokay with something. That or he'd just show leadership or be protective of his brother. Other than that, he had absolutely no depth whatsoever and he was easily forgettable. Really, I felt only interested in him cause he looked cool. I didn't like the little brother because he looks like a doof to me. But after watching the little bothers events and personality and backstory unfold a little bit (not enough I'd say) he was much more interesting and likeable.

Next up is the graphics. Graphics were good, I mean. I am unsure about the detailing, at times they felt not shaded enough, detailed enough, or they didn't flow together well enough. Though the graphics and displays and scenery was good enough to definitely warrant a second playthrough with your finger on the steam screencapture key, that's for sure. Definitely good desktop wallpaper material in here. Also can be aspring for some artists I can imagine.


There were some moments of tenseness in this game, surprisingly. As the game got progressively dark and took a really unexpected dip into limbo-like depressive stuff all of a sudden. I think there was only one or two parts that really made me have to actually pay attention to my controls, very sure it was once only. And that was a damn good part, glad it wasn't necessary to the story, felt very important to me though. And I like that, i'm glad I got a opportunity to side-track in the game and find things that were important to me instead of the characters. It was nice.

That being said, this games trip into darkness and doing scenarios that aren't often done in video games was truly surprising and i'm really glad they didn't regret any of the decisions they decided to do in it. Because I feel like that's what saved the game for me a little bit. It was a nice journey and it was fun and relaxing.
Most deaths in this game really only occur when the controls are a little too unclear, but you figure out what went wrong almost immediately, so it's not big deal.

That being said, I'd really like to give the developers a BIG thumbs up to one part they made me do. It was something I never want to do in a video game ever again, it just felt all kinds of wrong and messed up to me. I'd like to compliment another part about it, but. I won't, cause spoilers. But, it was good. And i'm glad you didn't reverse it.


Also, lastly. The music. ...It was really easy to ignore it. It really was. It wasn't bad by any means, but it wasn't anything to remember. When my mind actually did pick up some of the tracks, I was instantly dissuaded to bother youtube searching it because that same track felt like a reoccuring theme in any deep" moments. Whenever something interested happened or a cutscene happened
date: tracks that sound like that song I heard. Sounded just like remixed versions of it with added or removed instruments and spacing between instrument play times and so on so forth to fit the timing they wanted to match or feelings they wanted to convey in the cut scenes. So the only interesting track was pretty much just rehashed to me in a uninteresting way and most of the scenes were impactful. Even the ones that were supposed to bother you.\nAlso with that
recommended: I don't get why they put this skyrim-sounding song at the end of the game. It really made no sense

reviewText:
In Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons, you go along with two brothers on a journey to get some important medicine for their deadly wound father. It's necessary to play with a controller, because you have to move both brothers at the same time.
That can sometimes be very frustrating, but the great story, the beautiful sad soundtrack and the lovely graphics really make up for it.
This unique game has a gorgeous world with many beautiful details. The graphics are very cute, mostly the expressions of both brothers are quite realistic.  It is shown a really strong bond between Naia, the older brother and Naiee, the younger one. Both of them have simple, but striking personalities, for example Naiee is usually some kind of animal-loving jester, but he shows a deep traumatic fear towards water.
The uncommon music fits perfectly into all six landscape you will explore.
Another great point which I only recognize in this game is the language. You know exactly, how the characters feel and what they are trying to say, but you aren't able to understand the language itself, because it's only a fantasy language.

Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is a true marriage of gameplay and narrative. It will make you laugh and it will definitely make you cry at the end.  This game is a real must-have for all lonely and depressive people out there, for all of you who don't have much faith in their own abilities, for all of you who want to see how strong love and friendship can be, for all of you who maybe fear the future.

reviewText:
One of the most adorable and touching experiences I've had in gaming.

You control both brothers with a gamepad simultaneously and drive them through a journey to help their father. The characters speak gibberish, there is no dialogue or subtitles, but that doesn't put you off from the experience, to the contrary; it takes the focus beam and points it at emotions and surroundings more than objectives and achievements. You will appreciate the little things in this game that become huge, such as the environment that looks like it came out of a painting and how each brother has a different way of dealing with things. I caught myself stalling to look around for secrets or ways to mess with the locals more than I dare to admit. *clears throat*

10/10; Flawless, wonderful experience. It's ~ 3hrs of gameplay (or more if you go for the achievements), so you may want to get it on sale. Highly recommended anyways.


p.s. keep yourself hydrated ;_;

reviewText:
A game, so masterfully crafted, it's breathtaking;
Brothers: A tale of two sons puts you in the shoes of two young brothers (hence the name of the game), trying to help their father by finding a cure.
You venture out into the mysterious and strange lands, populated by creatures you'd not expect to exist.
Brothers is a game made solely for the purpose of telling a good, interesting story, which would be more than good enough to sell as a book.

The artwork and music are both ingenius and although the visuals may be outdated, they immerse you anyways.

At this point I'd like to point out the following things:
This game is ONLY playable via a compatible controller!
The visuals are not top notch, please view ingame-screenshots or watch a short video to see, if you're okay with that!
The story is VERY short. If you calculate achievement hunting into the mix, you'll barely scratch the 3 hour mark!
If you can look past all that, I'd say, that you should go pick it up. Otherwise I'd advise to wait for the game to be in sale!

I hope you found my review helpful and that it aided you deciding, wether or not to buy this product!

reviewText:
One of the games which are about the experience, not challenge.

Story has a simple premise and the gameplay is easy to handle which allows you to focus on the experience all the more, especially in the second half of the game (some parts near the end utilize the control mechanics in a way which adds a lot to the story - but I don't want to spoil it for you).

Level design is one of the best in the last 5-10 years. There are some puzzles but they're all very easy and you shouldn't have trouble with any of them.

The overall art style is stunning. Beautiful visuals (with many small events which happen in the background) and original score create a mesmerizing world which feels very much alive.

The game is quite short (~3-3.5 hours) so you will not spend a lot of time with it (recommended for those with huge backlogs).

Get it and play it, this game is definitely worth your money and time.

Recommended input method: Gamepad all the way. Controlling each character with one half adds a lot of depth, especially later on. Vibration capability further more extends the experience.

Hello everyone, my name is TreeTon!

Some people have commented that the game doesn't worth its price; however, I have to disagree with their opinion, even though I have purchased the game when it was on sale! The game is great, and the main future of the game is that the player allowed to use two protagonists (brothers) at the time!

Making a fictional language was the best idea of the developers, because the player is able to make his own story by understing the game the way he sees it. The story itself is great, and the game is not that long (about 3-4hrs), but believe me, it will be the best 3-4hrs of your life! The game is very unpredictable, because it is almost impossibe to say what is going to happen in the future, and the ending is very shocking.

I would like to say special thanks to the developers for giving me the opportunity to play this game and especially to record it!

Thanks for reading my review, and please, take a look at my channel!

reviewText: This game felt very complete to me. It was not particularly complex in any of its aspects, the individual challenges were very straightforward, the music was appropriate yet inconspicuous, and the dialogue (intentionally unintelligible) was also consciously, and sparingly included, but all of the aspects were synthesized perfectly. I was quite impressed with both the art and the controls, but more than anything, this game is about the story and the emotional connection to the characters. This game focuses on experiences that everyone has experienced and is concerned with expressing those experiences honestly, rather than ideally. I have to say it is one of my games of the year (though I probably play fewer games than many) and I highly recommend it to everyone.

reviewText: Amazing, one-session titleThis game is simply amazing. It seems like nothing great at first glance and I was unsure before buying it, but it was worth it. By worth it I mean the 1.49â‚¬ I payed, I don't think I'd recommend buying it for the full price.\nBrothers" is a very short game and I'd recommend playing it in one long session because the story really sucks you into the environment and it also takes a bit to get used to the unique gameplay mechanics. It took me just about 3h to finish the game
date:
but I derped two or three times. If I knew what to do at every little bit I would have been able to do it in 2.5h.

The Story
It's really not a special setting. Having to complete a far dangerous journey to save a relative is nothing new. But the way it's done is just mind-boggling! The emotions I felt for these characters living through lows and highs (especially the highs are normally rare and hard to implement in sad games!) of their lives really don't compare to anything I have felt in a video game before.
The only thing that isn't great about the story is that it is very linear. But that's okay.
Rating 9.5/10

Graphics & technical stuff
The graphics are really nothing special. The boys look kind of cute (not in that way! ;D) but the textures are boring. But that's not really the main focus of the game so that's okay.
The physics do bug out rather often to the point where it get's a little annoying. For instance right at the start you have to push a cart with both brothers. To pick up the handles of the cart you will have to stand at very specific places with the brothers otherwise it doesn't work. They also move rather jittery sometimes.
Rating 6/10

Summary:
Overall a definite recommendation

reviewText: Brothers is a perfect example of where I think video games should be going. More than anything else, I am incredibly impressed by Brothers' ability to integrate gameplay mechanics and storytelling in such a way that each complement each other. The thing is, despite video games being an interactive medium, few games seem to take full advantage of this fact. I've played games with great mechanics. I've also played games with great stories.  Hell, I've even played games with both great mechanics and great stories. But Brothers is even more than that. What this game manages to do is give emotional weight to gameplay mechanics. By doing this, Brothers takes full advantage of the agency of the player, deepening the emotional bonds produced over a relatively short few hours. I hope developers take a close look at this game.

There are titles where words are unnecessary, where a single utterance can easily ruin the idilliac atmosphere surrounding a simple, innocent yet mesmerizing narration.

Brothers - A tale of Two Sons easily embodies this description. It finds its strength in its simplicity which makes it innovative.

The decision of adopting a fictional language without subtitles immediately puts the players inside a real fantasy world, with no connection to reality. It feels like being dragged into that perfect place you'd love to live, perhaps the kind of place you can see in your dreams.
The visuals, the entities, the landscape and the invisible forces moving the fate of the two brothers, they all have dream-like features.

Buy? Likely. I was convinced to buy this game thanks to TotalBiscuit - I didn't know this game existed until I saw his video. Is this a great showpiece of gaming that made me cry? Honestly, no. I didn't cry. Whether that's the fault of the game or if I'm too emotionally unresponsive is impossible for me to answer, but you do have a good story based puzzler with a clever mechanic of controlling two characters with a separate analogue stick and trigger. I don't think that the tale alone of a random father who is on his deathbed thanks to an undescribed condition as well as the ending is enough to make me cry - gaming has desensitized me to death.

There is some gameplay contrivance, such as why is there a funky, switch activated bridge just to get to one family's house? Puzzles are cleverly implemented in my opinion, but all are simple to solved - you'll rarely if ever be stumped. This game has plenty of photogenic moments as shown by my screenshot library, and this can be completed by most around 3 hours. It's arguably pretentious, but I don't think it's trying to force some abstract artistic or literary vision.

This game, unfortunately, has some bugs and glitches that can spoil the fun a bit. I even had to start a level again, because the mechanism of the level simply didn't want to work. But, it is still pretty short, so you won't spend that much time.

You will have some good time with it.
Also, it is, at sales, at some pretty cheap prices.

reviewText:
A masterpiece; that's what Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is.

It's emotionally gripping with the storytelling as you watch the two brothers bond while adventuring to find healing water for their ill father. Straight from the beginning, you can tell that this isn't exactly a game suited for kids, as you watch your mother drown to her death in flashback cutscene, when the younger son, Naiee tragically tried to save her, but isn't able to do so in time. I don't wanna spoil anything, but the game is an adventure game that is charming, creepy and lastly, heartwrenching.

The gameplay starts when Naiee and his elder brother Nyaa carry their father to a doctor, and from there the doctor has them embark on an epic quest to find the healing water. During the epic quest, you encounter folk in the village, farmers, sheep, rabbits, mountain goats; friendly trolls, evil trolls, whales, invisible monsters; giants that fought to their death, wolves, griffins, and much more.

While you don't fight any of these beings, and really, only some of them are evil, (the mean trolls, a giant spider, wolves, and some angry cultists), you avoid them by controlling the two brothers. The game plays like a twin stick fighter or shooter, but as a 3rd person, over head view, and puzzle solving, one stick for each brother, and a trigger to interact with objects.

The game really is epic with the interactions, as you climb, swim, swing, fly, use torches, use various gears and handles; there's a large number of puzzle/interacting; but it's pretty straightforward.

The graphic style is reminiscent of Fable and Ico, but in its own way, and it works well as the game is gorgeous. The audio is perfect, the music and atmosphere really add to the charm of the game, as well as to the creepiness of certain areas (like the guy who tries to hang himself and you have to choice of stopping him, or the bloody rivers where the giants fought to their death, or the children whose bodies are hanging in the forests).

I managed through the game pretty well, but I have to say that the ending is f*cking depressing. It leaves an emotional impact unlike any game I've ever played.

10/10

reviewText:
Brothers uses a very interesting control mechanic, where either analog stick controls one of the two brothers. All levels are designed and take full advantage for this.
But that's not why you should play this game.

Brothers has no real speech throughout, and what music there is is perfectly matched to the levels. The art design is also beautiful, at times as if you're in a LOTR-kind world. You move through several environments here from villages to high mountains to a frozen world, yet all belong to the same world clearly and it is a wonderful journey. But that's not why you should play this game.

So many games try to touch emotion and portray a feeling of loss, but few succeed as well as Brothers does. One of the most impressive games ever made. Play it.
